This is my most favourite place in Zürich and I take all my friends there. Just a few minutes from main station it gives a wondeful overview of the Niederdorf and Züriberg and the Limmat. Just hang out for a few minutes and enjoy the fabulous view. The energies are wonderful!

The Lindenhof is a very nice elevated spot in the old town of Zurich. It is often crowded but still a kind of quite place very close to the Bahnhofstrasse. One has a nice view on the Limmat, the Niederdörfli on the side of the river, the ETH and UZH main buildings.. . Definitely

a short walk uphill through the narrow streets of old town will bring you to a small level area with low walls and plenty of trees which offers a wonderful variety of views across the city. we saw it at the end of winter and the lack of leaves on trees meant good views. the
Easy to go by foot from old town. Very nice and quiet place at least in March. Nice view over to city.
A good lookout over to the known Niederdorf (also a must to visit) and the river Limmat downtown Zurich, 10min walk from the Bahnhofstrasse
When I come to Zurich I always visit this place in the evening. Its nice little secluded place awaz from the rush of the streets. You can enjoy the silence and nice view of the city
The Lindenhof is a nice quiet spot in the middle of a bustling city. Great views over the old town and the Limat. A good place to sit and read a book.
Nice and free place to visit. Easy to walk from Zurich to Old Town. Good view to Zurich city and lake Zurich.

We spent some time during our walk about Zurich sitting in the park and admiring the view. This park doesn't have much to it, however the spot is a nice place to sit and relax. It is quiet and very peaceful and was a great spot to take a rest from sightseeing. The houses
I went alone and spent a couple of hours there, just wandering and getting to know the park. The view is beautiful, and the people around is very helpful

If you have just a few hours left before you have to catch your train in the nearby trainstation, than take this 10 minutes walk up to the Lindenhofplatz an enjoy the view over the old-town of Zurich and the Grossmünster Church.
Climbed up to the Lindehof area to explore it. very nice view of the city and river. Highlight of the area for me was watching locals play chess on the life size board.

This is how we get a quick breath of fresh air amongst the city. In the day time we meet here for a picnic, by night we come and enjoy wine at dusk. Quite a few of my favorite memories take place here. One night we played batchi ball with new friends from all over the world.

This place has a rich history (where the women defended the the city by marching with brooms and banging the wash basins) and offers a very romantic view of the old part of Zurich, University and more. Must see place in Zurich.

As the guide book said this is a wonderful view, for us half way through a walking tour of old Zurich

i think it's better to go up there during the summer. the street that lead there also very nice, go there.
Definitely worth a quick visit as you explore old town on the right bank along Rennweg, Nice foto ops!
in summer days, a quiet place 5min walk from the crowded bahnhofstreet. nice view to old town, peaceful. take your picnic or take away to enjoin up there on the green

My visit here was half an hour after a climb to the Grossmunster tower and in comparison Grossmunster beats Lindenhof. Though the view of Niederdorf was good anyway.

It's worth the effort to make your way here for the vantage point it gives you out over the Limmat river and the old town of Zürich. I found it a little tricky to find this place, but once I got here it was certainly worth the effort.
Oldest part of Zurich where you can view old town of Zurich and across the lake Uphill hike to open square. Water fountain in middle gives a relaxed atmosphere.

This is a lovely place for a view of the city and architecture from above. The narrow streets leading up to the open plaza are lined with cute shops and cafes. One of the best places for a photo of the skyline of Zurich.

Joined a walking tour and the guide took us to this place for a very nice view of the city. Passing small streets and short climb to get there, don't worry if you're thirsty as there is fountain at the park you can refill your water bottle there.

Tranquility in the midst of a global finance center. Kids running helter smelter while older visitors play chess on an immense board. Did I mention the views which are exquisite especially to the east.

We came here on our Old Town walking tour and I popped back for another visit (by accident) later in the day. While it was wet it was still a good place to visit. It is the site of an old Roman fortress (not that you could tell that now) and offers good views across the river.
nice view from up here and if you like to play some chess you can do that to over there, always people playing. nice stroll then down through an other old part of Zurich

A small stroll upwards from the river and you are rewarded with fine views from Lindenhof. The river, mountains, the churches and city lie just below.

on the left side of the Limmat, you need to pass Lindenhofplatz. The view on the right bank is unprenable. Also you are in the middle of the leftbank old town. Nice place to eat your sanswich in summer

In the evenings, enjoy a relaxing moment in hectic and xmas-sy downtown. You can see the old town and some major landmarks before going back to the shoppers's dreams or to enjoy the nighttime xmas decoration with many thousand artificial stars over the streets.

This place is perfect for a nice view of the old town and it is only a short stroll away from the main street. It has a nice. relaxed feeling and it is not crowded at all. In the square there are a few giant chess boards which everyone can use.
The promenade allows you a great city view whith unparalled sights of St Peter and Fraumüster chuches.

Pleasant walk up to the park through the streets of the old town and lovely panoramic views of the river and old town from the top. Well worth the walk.
A good view of the city. You can take good pictures of old the city. During the winter, the park is not that special. Probably, autumn or spring would be better period to visit.

Really loved Lindenhof. A people's square. Just enjoy the leisure peace and view. Survey the skyline and looked at the opposite buildings and mountains. Lovely!

one of the best spots to see the view of Zurich, and it s free. Good for taking place with background of Limnat river, university, and eth etc

Only if you are in that area of town should you bother with this. There are much better overlooks to the river and city than this. We took the polybahn up to the university which I thought had better views. Also Mt. Uetliberg is great too for lookouts.
Thisplace has its own fun. It gives a good view of the hustle bustle of the zurich. You sepnd an hour or tow and enjoy your beer while having a good view. Ofcourse , we vistetd in the summer.

Best view of the Limmat. Old streets and a lovely, relaxed park. Great place to rest and enjoy the view.

The historic Lindenhof (5mins walk from the main station) has a great view all over the old town of Zurich! Highly recommendable spot.

Walking through the narrow streets of the beautiful old city of Zurich, you may find yourself in a nice square, with wonderful views of the Limmat river, The Church and the entire center of the city. But also read about the history of the place, which is related to women
A quiet spot With a wonderful view of the river and the town on the other side. Huge trees give shade which makes this a Nice Place to relax on a hot day

Great views and a lovely park! Definitely worth the time and walk uphill. Not far at all and easy to get to from the Old Town.
Walk a little away from the main shopping street and see the history of old Zurich. Must see is Lindenhof.

Beautiful city view and small walk away from the lake. it has a fountain at top. Also small garden for kids on the way up. its quiet and nice place to sit and relax.

The place to go when visiting Zurich as it gives you a nice view over the river Limmat. It is a nice stroll up the hill and then suddenly you find this beautiful place in the middle of the old town of Zurich. Definitely a must.

I am from Zurich and I love to go to the Lindenhof to have a beer with some friends! The view is lovely and its between the Bahnhofstrasse and the Limmat, so its very near to the other tourist spots :)

Going two minutes up hill you have a nice view to rhe old town. Maybe you can manage the plan of tze city a little bit better now. Its calm and quiet to rest under the trees after long walk/ shopping.

This is a sweet little park overlooking the river and Old Town Zurich. It has a nice view of town, and it's a good place to read a book on a bench!

Somewhere that is breathtaking. With the bird view of Zurich. The river, the tower, the birds, and the mountains far far away. Would like to walk around and re-visit and re-visit (re-re-visit) once and again. Among one of the top ranked places in Zurich.

Really a lovely place to be when in Zurich! You have an awesome view of the old part of the city and you can relax there without being disturbed by people.

Very nice place for a good weather day~ 
You can enjoy the quiet in the center of Zurich and get the nice view.

Nice place, where we can see beautiful view of the city from above.
Good view of the city from this location. Nice place to spend time with kids
Real view point of Zurich city. One can get an Amazing view of Zurich city.

Beautiful scenery. I was lucky to have a nice day during my visit and the walk in the city was amazing and refreshing. Would recommend everyone coming to Lindenhof hill for some chill/meditation time and appreciate this wonderful life you have been given :)
Beautiful views over the old town and towards the mountains. Benches to sit on and admire it. Can be very busy with buses of tourists arriving from time to time

You can see big part of Zurich from here. Amazing spot.
Awesome really love this place👍
Just Amazing, I will be back 😊

The most beautiful city view in the world.
Great view
Amazing view of the city and historic story
Nice place, great views.
Perfect view
You get a nice panorama sight of Zurich. Nice small shops while going to the top.
Great place to visit
Great view and experience of Zurich. Worth visiting both during day and night. Grab a coffee or an icecream and enjoy the view.
A peaceful park to enjoy the view of Zurich alongside the river. The town feels like a blast into the past as you're walking through cobblestone streets.
Beautiful place in the middle of Zurich. Grab a "Heissi Marroni" and enjoy the view :)
Beautiful when the weather accomodates
Awesome views.
Nothing to write home about. Tiny square with some trees.
Cute little park
Nice place for recreation
Great view of the city
Great view over the Limmat and Zurich’s Highlights!
One of the small hill to view the city of zurich. but one should visit a place very near to zoological museum to experience another city view of zurich.
I Always recommend tourist to check this small hill. The view is beautiful.
Great view over the city.
Beautiful views in Zurich
Beautiful place
Nice views of the river
Best place to see zurich from the top , nice garden you can relax and enjoy the scene of lovely Zürich:):)
A nice spot to overview the city
A park that is also an old Roman ruins supposedly where Zurich began. Interesting spot with intetrsting shopping on old narrow streets nearby.

Nice relaxing place to come and take a break from the city. Nice views over the old town and river. Several benches for sitting and a water fountain. Also a couple of outdoor chess boards where people gather to watch the players compete with each other.
Excellent view of the Zurich area from the top of the hill. I visited during the sunset hour, which was beautiful.

One of the most historic spots in Zurich with free restrooms, playground, water fountain, chessfield and beautiful view over the oldtown. The hill at the small passage from the River "Limmat", who marks the end of Lake Zurich, is settled …
Very nice view

One of my favourite places in Zürich. You have a beautiful view over the city and it's nice and quiet.
Often there are groups of friendly tourists.
There are benches to sit and drink or eat something you brought with you. Usually there is enough space to sit.
Nice location
Nice view to old town of Zurich
Super and very clean

A historic place where cars are not allowed is one of the major tourist attraction. One can approach this through narrow winding, climbing lanes. The top offers a scenic view of the river and the city of Zurich. This place is usually not crowded and offers a good opportunity for those who wants to explore the place.
Great view of the city. The park is also a good place to relax.
Nice view from the view point.
A beautiful sight  of  Zurich!
Nice view and located in the city. Easy to get there by walk.
Enjoyed my walk and the great vistas.

Nice park on the top of a hill in Zurich the place started as a Roman Fort and changed over the years ending up as a place of tranquility with benches statues and a fountain. Amazing views over the river and of all part of the city. A little bit of a hike goukn up.

This is a small hill with good views of the city. You can reach here by steps. Not wheelchair accessible. There are trees on top of the hill. And a fountain. Not sure if it is drinking water. There is a big chess board on the ground with benches around it. It is a good place to relax and spend an afternoon

This is a beautiful place with couple of trees and benches be to sit around. You get the beautiful view of the river and the city. This place is peaceful to spend time in the evening eithee alone or with family.
Panoramic view of the city 👍
Good place visit if you have a few hours at the airport to catch the connection. Easy connectivity and walking distance from Zurich HB

lovely place, with a frightening past; a former place for executions! ;O ( ... but today a lovers place! best view over Niederdorf and Zürich Hill. A MUST for visitors. can spend a whole afternoon there, by having picknick, or with kidz. never too crowded.
Decent view
Calm place. Good to spend few hours in afternoon.
Not bad at all.
Great great place...

text.quote: University-run city garden with 9000 global plant species, 3 tropical glass domes, a meadow & pond.
trip:
Overview Affiliated with the University of Zürich, these large gardens feature a huge variety of plants from around the world. Suggested Duration:1-2 hours Address:
Zollikerstrasse 107, Zurich 8008 SwitzerlandMap
The botanical garden is a real gem in Zurich. Don't miss out 3 greenhouses, the entrance is a little hidden, a Lotus pond.
It is a very nice (and free!) garden. The only sad thing is that our dog was not allowed in the premises.

Visited to kill time waiting for a flight. Easy to find - but on a cold wet day not so much fun. Pity there is not a lot of signage for anyone whose German is rudimentary! Hot houses were a blessed relief as was the delightful black cat which accompanied us on the start of the

It was great to visit this Botanical Garden in the Fall - fewer tourists and still absolutely gorgeous! Locals come here to sit on the benches and have their lunch - I'm so jealous they have this so near their workplace! Stop by the neighboring, free Ethnographic Museum too if

The (new) Botanical Garden (established in 1976) used to be private but now it’s part of the University of Zurich and definitely, it worth a visit, no matter if it’s summer or winter-but I’m not going to lie, the beast season to visit is spring-. Don’t miss the Tropical –bubble
Nice garden to walk around. Autum is not the best time to visit there, but worth anyway. Short distance walk from city.

This garden is highly recommendable for anyone. It offers the perfect amount of information and it is beautifully located in the middle of Zurich. The great aspect of this garden is that it is a garden that actually focusses on plants unlike other botanical gardens that just

After reading reviews on Trip Advisor and from the tourism websites, we had higher expectations. First, it was very difficult to find, even using Google Maps on my phone. It's on the University campus, but there's no signage guiding the way. The gardens were nice, but have

It was an experience of gorgeous views and great looking landscapes, but the older ladies that worked there in a very mean and aggressive tone chased us out while we were still packing our stuff to leave. So if you go, leave before 6 to avoid their scathing comments.
If you want to spend a couple hours in the middle of the nature, just for relax, it’s perfectly place. It’s free of charge

This is actually free to go around- not many places in Switzerland are free so enjoy it! We had a lovely couple of hours meandering around the different areas- going into the 3 different huge greenhouse canopies to see the tropical and desert plants. There are areas of
This garden is very beautiful and offer scenic views especially for photographers and even for other people.
I wish I knew this is the cheapest buffet in Zurich since students eat there... a bit away from the center but if you want to eat real food for less it's awesome.

We have been in few best botanical gardens in Europe, but we went to see this one as well. It was surprisingly small so we walked each area twice :) It's not reach, but really nice to walk, both outside and inside tropical areas. We were in summer, so walking outside under the

A beautiful hidden gem in Zurich, perfect if you need a chilled activity away from the hustle and bustle of the city. If you don't speak German it's a bit difficult to learn about the plants directly from the plaques next to them, but their latin names are there so it's easy to

Very nice small garden for a short visit with family. The Garden contains mostly tropical plants neatly sorted in few chambers and offers many more home plants for sale. It is a breath of rain forest amongst Swiss Alps, indeed small but worth visiting
a beautiful small jewel away from the buzz of the city centre. the conservatories are a warm refuge during winter. All of this is free and really worth paying a visit for nature lovers.

When we visited the Botanical Garden in late-summer, there were still many beautiful specimens in bloom. If only because we got to see these unusual varieties, it was worth finding this off-the-beaten path garden space. That said, we were very confused by the layout of the

We found this park by chance, walking around and following our feet! It was a really nice surprise as we love to explore green points in cities! Several trees were full of little red fruits that made it special although chilly and wintery the atmosphere was beautiful. Surprise
Secluded, quite shady, not very large. Upper deck is nice with 4 small garden areas in the middle. Loved the kaki tree in fron the the institute!

I enjoyed my time at the botanical gardens. It's not the best or the biggest, but it's lovely. I especially liked the Tropical Domes with the fish exhibit. And it's free! This is important as almost everything, including most museums & churches in Zurich, have a hefty entrance

A peaceful place to walk, free entry and for the plant enthusiast many of the plants are labelled. Three large circular glass houses with plants from different biomes, subtropical, humid tropical and hot dry climates are represented. Outside an interesting selection of plants

Easily accessible via public transportation (and free!) this is a beautiful nature escape in the middle of busy and lively Zurich. Three different greenhouses (three climates) invite you to explore and the garden itself is beautiful with plenty of grassy areas to sit or lie down

Went with high expectations but was disappointed. The gardens aren’t well looked after and need more care. Plenty of weeds, and looking overgrown. Maybe it’s because I visited late in the season but it also looks like some of the funding to support this free exhibit has been
What a wonderful place to stroll. The Gardens are a retreat that soothes the soul. You can explore many treasured paths, ponds, and quiet moments.

This is not only an extraordinary botanical garden, it is also part of the university. In this incredible place you are going to learn about diversity. Various ecosystems are displayed with explanation of almost every plant you see. If you are looking for a peaceful and

like any other garden...it requires maintenance and that's why it's average. There are plants that don't have a name on it so you keep your ignorance at the same level as before. It's worth a visit especially on the hot days of summer
Free! In Zurich, a rarity. Kids will enjoy the biosphere bubbles. There is a lovely cafeteria on site. Nice place to spend a quiet hour or two if you are in the area.

Compact and free this garden was interesting. They had several biomes represented and the open gardens outside were easy to get around. Not going to occupy a huge amount of time but a great place for a picnic or to sit and relax.
Its newly renovated glass houses are definitely worth seeing, and also the rest of the place is pretty cool. Especially when considering that it has free entrance :)

Really enjoyed these gardens. Same exhibit would have cost at least £15 a head int he UK but in Zurich it's free. Only downside is the cafe only accepts cash or contactless. So if you have a UK bank card and no cash, you're going without

This is a nice free attraction but definitely not a must see or do while in Zurich. There is a peaceful pond you can sit next to or pack a lunch near the pond. There are three buildings full of greenhouse plants to explore along with outdoor plants. Its a free attraction

Over different levels do you find interesting plants and trees, with a small green house. Lovely to walk around, with one of the cities rivers next to it. There is a lot of seating all over the garden - especially when it's sunny, it's peaceful but great. I often take a book
The inside gardens are really cool. It takes around 30-60minutes but its really nice inside. It's for free

The botanical garden is a really beautiful garden in the city of Zurich, it's quite big and includes tropical green houses too. Worth of note, is that's for free, which is really nice since it allows to everyone to appreciate and enjoy spending some time there, even for an hour,

I visited in February so will acknowledge that the garden would not have been at its best. The garden is large enough for a morning or afternoon visit but will not occupy the whole day. The highlights must include the greenhouses which, being covered, make the gardens a good
Visited this place in September and most for the plants did not bloom due weather. My first stop in swiss.

Literally, this is an urban oasis. Smacked in the middle of Zürich, you find the serenity of expansive gardens, housing plants from throughout the world. If your day is getting busier than you like, make an escape to the botanical garden and recharge.

Somewhat tired & run down displays. Nice for a stroll - but I think after all the spectacular views we enjoyed while travelling through Switzerland we were left somewhat disappointed with our experience with botanic gardens.

Visited here in early September, and many items were out of bloom. Gardens were very nice, but we have been to over 25 gardens around the world and this is average. The three conservatory buildings were very enjoyable.
The botanical garden is really cool, with a range of flora from select locations across the globe - there are also three domed greenhouses home to a range of plants from the tropics

This is such a relaxed place away from the maddening crowd. I is never too busy. There are places to sit down and have a picnic. If you want to get away from it all then pop in here, it is so close to the city centre and yet is so peaceful.
We were here in September and the gardens were well worth a visit. There is a wonderful area for sitting and enjoying nature. There are chairs supplied and the locals were certainly enjoying the sun.
I had read this was a top spot in Zurich to visit and was not let down. There are a number of hot houses with exotic plants to visit as well as walking trail through out the Garden.

We were looking forward to a nice garden walk, but found an unkept garden area instead. I'm not sure why the area was in such disrepair, while the rest of the city is so beautiful. Save your steps for another venue.

The botanical garden is a good option if you want to walk in the nature and enjoy the warm weather for a couple of hours without leaving the city. I really liked the tropical section and the piranha pools.

Beautiful and lovely garden in the city, very refreshing. Excellent plant collection including tropical rain forest plants in three greenhouse dome. Other good thing, no entrance fee - all free. Highly recomended

The gardens are right down from the apartment we were renting. Beautiful gardens with plants marked. There are 3 huge domes that house rainforest like plants. One also contains a small Aquarium. The day we went was a nice Sunday. We took a ball and played in an open area. There
Perfect place for studying and for relaxation. The singing of the bird is marvelous . It has some rare plants and a giant tree from thailand

Interesting to see just how many different plants grow in the very well laid out Botanical garden. Also includes three Bio-Domes (a bit like the Eden Centre in Cornwall albeit smaller in size). It would be interesting to see what it looks like in the other seasons on subsequent
nice place to spend some time! lots of beautiful plants. even nice in winter, because it's warm inside. free of charge! :)

The botanic garden is situated near the trendy Seefeld area just a few minutes of the hustle and bustle of Seefeldstrasse. It offers a great variety of flora and fauna as well as several greenhouses each of which is showcasing a different geographical zone, from dry desert

The gardens are a very peaceful way to spend 1-2 hrs. We went in march the sun was shining and it was a very pleasant relaxing couple of hours. Take some sandwiches and you can chill in the garden and take In the view. There are three domes to visit which are nice.

Stopped here while riding a rental bike in Zurich, Switzerland. So glad that I did because it was absolutely beautiful. It was a great place to enjoy the view, the scenery as well as a place to simply "stop" and reflect. Quite peaceful.

... here in the 'Garden of Eden' it never gets boring for me because there's so many different things to explore in the botanical garden, people come in and find out about themselves, great place, best early in the morning when they open the gate or the hour before they close

Quite fantastic collection, amazingly maintained garden. I went in autumn, which is perhaps not the best time for most plants, however, I especially loved the tropical domes, and they didn't seem to be seasonal.

I didn't have a whole lot of time here, and judging from some of the pictures, I missed at least one entire section of the garden. But it's a very nice place to go to get some quiet. There's a bit of a maze of trails going in different directions, and it was fun to explore and
A very good place to have a moment to think about live. Have a nice view and can learn about plants and flowers.

The botanical garden is part of the University of Zurich. It has seasonal plants and flowers in their prime at "their" time of the year. It is used for educational purposes, especially for elementary-age children. The garden is really peaceful, and spending time just sitting

A pleasant place to walk around. Probably nothing really unique. The perennial beds are a bit of a mish-mash but that seems to be the "new" style. Has a cafeteria with a salad bar. Greenhouses are standard plant habitats (the same design company must be doing all the gardens). A

Best on a sunny day, but even in the wet you can enjoy the bio-domes. Plenty of space to walk and sit and of course lots of plants and trees. For a leafy longer walk: Head up Weineggstrasse and Buchenweg to the Tram Museum and then follow the path down from just past the museum
It's really worth to visit the garden, even in fall. It's huge with 3 greenhouses and beautiful plants.

The Botanical Garden of Zurich is a hidden gem. So much to see spread out on beautiful grounds with its gorgeous architectural landscaping. Includes a café. A very interesting part of Zurich with a country side flair yet impressive villas from the late 19th/early 20th century.

Great way to spend a few hours, especially on a budget at it is a free attraction. Perfect for taking the kids for a walk around the grounds where they can burn off some energy and maybe learn a thing or two. Unfortunately the information plaques are all in German but it there

We took the tram and then walked quite a way to find this spot - it was marked on our tourist map and we love gardens of all sorts. It was a bit of a hike up through the entrance. The flower gardens were unkempt, perhaps the wild look was the goal, although we saw lots of

We are both keen gardeners and nature lovers so decided to take a break from the hustle and bustle of the city to visit the Botanical Garden. It was easy to find and we walked there from our hotel on Seefeldstrasse. What a welcome surprise! We enjoyed the tropical houses but
One can spend hours at this botanical garden, so much flora and fauna to see. Also it is very relaxing just to walk around
Cross this botanical garden off your list of to-do's while in Zurich. It's out of the way and not worth the time. I love nature and flowers but somehow this garden missed its mark.

A very beautiful garden, quite small but full of different scenic corners. don't miss the green houses, and especially the tropical one! It is open for free, and makes a lovely place to wonder about in nice weather. Highly recommended!
Amazing place to visit for people who want to see different plants - the range of plants in the garden is good to keep you engrossed for couple of hours

The gardens are free of charge and since we had one hour we dropped by and did not disappointed. The park is nice and welcome and the tropical houses we very interesting but there are no explabation in English which is very disappointing. The toilet had no soap to wash hands,
Whilst the three domes hold the major attractions the balance of the gardens are badly overrun with weeds, something many of us can see at home ??

We spent a couple hours visiting the tropical domes and walking around the gorgeous grounds (lot of hills, wear good shoes). Unfortunately, many of the information cards are not in English and are too technical for a basic German speaker. There is a small café.
When you're bored with walking by the lake, this might be the next best thing. A pleasant way to kill an hour or two.
I was there a few days ago and it is great to walk around at different stages of growth in the gardens. I go there every few weeks and it is great.
The botanical garden is located in a nice residential area of Zurich. It has two main buildings/greenhouses, which are lush with orchids and tropical plants.

Spring has finally sprung here in Zurich & whilst the blossom trees are a stunning sight in the streets of Zurich, these gardens (which have been extensively replanted in recent times & therefore not nearly developed enough to either identify much, nor indeed admire). However

One of the nicer botanical gardens in the world I have visited. Not far from the centre of the bustling city of Zurich it is a quiet oasis with tropical houses and a very nice alpine garden. A good place to view plants but also a nice quiet place to sit and read a book.

This botanical garden is a wonderfully peaceful and relaxing spot. The location is convenient as it is even possible to walk there from downtown. It offers a lovely place to spend a day. There is a portion that is lightly wooded and another that is pastoral with a sloping
Super beautiful place. lots of large and small plants. plants from different types of climate, nice eatery and gift shop.

The garden is beautiful even during the winter months. It is not as magnificent as it would be in spring since there are not too many colors apart from green and brown but isn't this part of the cycle of nature? It is still nice to admire the various plants, flowers and trees

October is never the best time to visit a garden, but the selection of plants seemed haphazard and poorly laid out. Regardless, I appreciated the variety of winding paths through them. The treat is the hothouses, which you don't often get free access to.

We like to visit botanic gardens as we live in Kew. We had been to the lovely collection of succulents at Sukkulenten-Sammlung on the west bank of the lake and thought it was superb. The botanic garden was a real disappointment. It is very small and has a nasty building in
Pleasant and very well maintained, offers pleasant hours. I recommend to anyone who wants to be in leisure hours
It is build as a park, having few additional buildings, dedicated to particular theme, such as rain forest It is very clean, well treated and worth the visit

This place is bit hidden and not very easy to find. I seems a hidden gem that is mostly used by locals. It is beautiful and nice just to walk through the area and see and enjoy all those plants. It is not made a a "pure'" attraction and you cannot expect guided tours or a museum

The Zurich Botanical Garden is a wonderful compact, but very comprehensive garden. There are many spots throughout the garden where you can just sit and enjoy a peaceful lunch among the trees. There are three glass domes with a large variety of plants from around the world.

This could have been an attractive spot in Zurich. Unfortunately, we felt there is no interest to make it a tourist attraction site. The Entrance is free of charge. There were no sign to guide yo through your visit. There are some good plant but lake organization. We enjoyed

The garden has several different areas with lots of different plants. We saw locals enjoying the sun bathing on grass, tadpoles swimming, it's a very relaxing and fun place. The tropical plants domes were very interesting too. Free to visit. Definitely worth visiting.

This is a lovely gem in Zurich - beautiful and peaceful. Skip the restaurant - it is terrible but enjoy the park, bring a picnic if you can - sit on the grass and enjoy this precious place. Do visit the greenhouses. You can easily spend an afternoon or a full morning here,

Remember, these comments are for tourists, not people from the city about which we write. For native citizens of Zurich, by all means go to the Botanical Garden--a great education for your children and a nice diversion for all. But for travelers, I must report that this garden
There was a Triathlon taking place and unfortunately much of the area was blocked off due to the race. What we did see was pretty...but we missed a great portion of it.

With reluctance, we entered the botanical garden. But, upon getting inside... we were astonished to see the floral treat. From tiny to large, plain to colourful... just amazing variety of flowers. There is a nice restaurant also inside. Don't miss it!

Indoor greenhouse with plants and arid plants section, outdoor ponds with lotus flowers, labeled plants for you to learn from This place is big and beautiful, you could spend an entire day here. Highly recommended.
Good collection of tropical plants, but very few from other areas. There is still lots of places to expand and introduce more species.

Pleasure to visit such beautiful place like this one.When in Zurich a must. Great for family and kids.Great break if you are in Zurich for business or couples.Good transportation(trams and buses)Highly recommended.

Easy to get to by public transport - bus as well as various trams. A really very wonderful botanical garden; large, well-labelled, beautifully landscaped. There are three interconnected glasshouses for tropical plants. It's all a hilly place, and the splashes of color on the

We went here and were not disappointed. The place is peaceful with lots of greenery and fresh are. There are many flowering plants and well as other medicinal plants, bushes, shrubs, and trees. There is a small pond and three biomes. There are many upslopes and down slopes to

The Botanical Garden of Zürich University is a free attraction. It is situated about 20-min walk away from the old town. The collection is planted on a hill with nice views to the lake and the city. Very nice tropical greenhouses of a shape of cupolas. This is a place to relax
My Wife went with a friend. My Wife is a plants person and could have spent all day, but her friend was not. So my Wife will have to go back to take it all in!
This is a nice place to spend time with your family and kids. The garden is well maintained with a variety of plants. The garden is quiet and well maintained.

Very pleasant wandering around this fairly extensive bot garden which has a range of plant habitats. It's a great place to relax with a picnic or visit the very nice tea room. It has a lake with 3 biomes....like the Eden Centre only on smaller scale.

The botanical garden is a short tram ride from the city center. The outdoor gardens are very peaceful and a great place to visit on a sunny day. The biospheres of tropical and arid areas are very well done. Great displays of herbs and medicinal plants.

This is a lovely place for a walk or picnic in the sunshine. It's not very sheltered so it's better on a dry day. There are three domed green houses to hide from the rain but they don't take long to walk round. Overall, it's an excellent place considering it's free.

The Zurich Botanical Garden would undoubtedly be splendid in summer but in March it is still sleeping - except in the glass domes that house the exotic collections. These were amazing. Extremely well arranged and tended, and free! That compares favourably with, say, Kew
The gardens are 5 minutes walk from my office. In spring or summer when the weather is good I often go to eat my lunch there in the peace and quiet.

While the outdoor garden is quite average (more of a park), don't miss the tropical domes which contain a wide variety of interesting flora. Despite free admission, it is being very well taken care of - well worth a visit.

We visited the Old Botanical Garden, which is in downtown. Worth a visit if you have time to spend in a quiet place, surrounded by 300-year trees. We missed the Botanical Garden, which is larger and off-town.
This is really a silent oasis in Zürich. Nice place to walk with the family or just lie on the grass and read a book.

Many types of plants, great place for family, or even solo visit. Spend time on sunny day, do not forget to bring your books if you would like to spend hours here. It would be great to put the pictures of the plant on their guide paper.

My wife is a plant person so this trip had to be on our agenda. I thought it was a little challenging to figure out how get there so here is what I learned: take #11 streetcar from Bürkliplatz to Hegibachplatz. After you exit, look for the sign for the Garden (in Deutsch), then
Really enjoyed this visit. Because they are part of the University they are more "working gardens", than tourist gardens, but very well kept with everything labelled.
This is a nice botanical garden and a good place to get away from the many people in the city. Worth a visit since it is free.

As far as botanical gardens go this is different ......... In a good way. Easy to get to, although the day we went there were diversions because of track work. Gardens seem to be unkempt but there are labels on everything so it isn't though they are weeds. Downside is that

The Botanical Gardens (actually the new location - the old gardens being in the old city) were easily reached by tram and bus. The people in the Visitors Center in the main train station (Hauptbahnhof) were most helpful in planning the trip for us. The gardens are a pleasant

The three new domed glass houses are great and feature plants from three different climate zones. It's refreshing to see such a well maintained park with educational walks open for free to everyone. Also usually not many people come here, so it's mostly quiet and serene. Only
This place has samples of European and world vegetation and is a nice break of all the shopping you can have in Zurich. Worth the visit in a sunny day.

While no heavyweight in terms of botanical gardens, the plants here are interesting and the entry via the stairs past the wildflower beds is beautiful. Amusing seeing plants we regard as ordinary in Brisbane, Australia, being treated with such care in this climate!

The Biological gardens were worth half a day or more. Plants well signed in various climatic zones. Some stunning flowers from all over the world. Particularly enjoyed the domed atmospheres eg steamy rainforest, desert area .Tranquil grassed areas to sit and enjoy the peace,
well laid out and easy walking. It was a good day though crisp, I can imagine that in good sunlight it is magnificent.

Awesome location to relax and gaze at all kinds of plants, if you where in zurich and missed this place, go back immediatly. In almost every major city you'll find such jewels, this is definitely one of them

whilst looking for something cheap to do in the city we decided to head to the botanical gardens which is actually free to get into. Its not a big area but the plants they have are beautiful and its very well maintained. The domes are basically big hot houses with some great

This is basically a park however, there are three large recently renovated domed greenhouses that are worth a visit. There is a small exhibition when you enter the greenhouses with some information (all in German).

The botanical gardens are a great place to escape the stress of the city. We spent the last day of the year here in lovely sunshine. Obviously, there is not that much to see plantwise in the middle of winter, but the three (newly renovated) big greenhouses all made up for that.
Its worth visiting. The garden is really health and organized. Lots of different climate types and an incredible green diversity. Really nice fruit tree collection from over the world.
You look for a quiet place to escape the rush of the city by yourself or with your significant other? This is the place. Beware to keep your watch close by as time will fly on this serenity Island.

The gardens are accessed on public transit with Tram #2 or #4 to Hoschgasse and then approximately a 10 minute walk up the hill. The main gardens open at 07.00 and the greenhouses opens from 09.30 until 17.00. The three main greenhouses were renovated and opened to the public

We visited mid July 2013 and maybe it was the heat but I have to say I felt like it wasn't worth the trip. From the tram stop you walk about 2 or 3 blocks down a hill then up a hill to get to the green houses. The green houses were quite small, very warm, and there wasn't much
The botanical garden is such a beautiful place to spend some time. I'm so happy that it is open again after the restoration of the three futuristic looking buildings.
A lovely excursion through a well kept and tended garden, an oasis of total sublimity in a city that is already well laid back

I have been to various botanical gardens and this was the least impressive, there wasn't anything really bad with it, just there wasn't a lot there, and for all the beauty of Zürich this isn't a place I will bring friends and family when they visit

Beautiful variety of plants, small pond, quite neighbourhood and newly commissioned tropical house complex. Very accessible from the city center but may not be access friendly to disabled people due to landscape. Free entrance and restaurant available (did not get to use it).
Enjoyed wondering around the gardens, which have a sense of rural nature, lovely sweeping meadows and lots of exotic color spots, delightful.
these gardens are one of a city's treasures, zurich's smaller but quite as good as rome's, oasises in the bustle of the city

This Botanical Garden is not that big as a usual Botanical Garden. If you have some spare time and you like to be on your own or with your children it's a really try. Quite a couple of bench where you can sit, or lay and read a book or just look the children running around and

I'm a big plant and garden lover and always visit botanic gardens wherever I go, but this one didn't appeal to me. It's not very big (for a botanic garden) and there's not much to see in Winter (March), contrary to what they claim. Moreover, the glasshouses (domes) are closed
Nice outdoor gardens & indoor gardens. Huge space for little kids to run around. If the weather nice, it is a lovely place for a picnic. Picnic tables are available in the outside gardens.

once a month except in winter, they offer themed evening tours with the possibility of a seasonal meal at the university restaurant, that they open especially for this occasion on evenings. We were on a tour themed edible plants. Very interesting, and the food was great.

text.wiki:
The Fraumünster (German pronunciation: [fʁaʊ̯ˈmʏnstɐ]; lit. in English: Women's Minster, but often wrongly translated to [Our] Lady Minster) is a church in Zürich which was built on the remains of a former abbey for aristocratic women which was founded in 853 by Louis the German for his daughter Hildegard. He endowed the Benedictine convent with the lands of Zürich, Uri, and the Albis forest, and granted the convent immunity, placing it under his direct authority. Today, it belongs to the Evangelical Reformed Church of the canton of Zürich and is one of the four main churches of Zürich, the others being the Grossmünster, Prediger and St. Peter's churches.


== History ==
In 1045, King Henry III granted the convent the right to hold markets, collect tolls, and mint coins, and thus effectively made the abbess the ruler of the city.
Emperor Frederick II granted the abbey Reichsunmittelbarkeit in 1218, thus making it territorially independent of all authority save that of the Emperor himself, and increasing the political power of the abbess. The abbess assigned the mayor, and she frequently delegated the minting of coins to citizens of the city. A famous abbess during this time of great power was Elisabeth of Wetzikon.
However, the political power of the convent slowly waned in the fourteenth century, beginning with the establishment of the Zunftordnung (guild laws) in 1336 by Rudolf Brun, who also became the first independent mayor, i.e. not assigned by the abbess.
The abbey was dissolved on 30 November 1524 in the course of the reformation of Huldrych Zwingli, supported by the last abbess, Katharina von Zimmern.
The monastery buildings were destroyed in 1898 to make room for the new Stadthaus. The church building today serves as the parish church for one of the city's 34 reformed parishes. Münsterhof, historically the main square and marketplace of the medieval city, is named for the abbey. Gesellschaft zu Fraumünster cultivates the traditions of the former nunnery convent.


== Chagall windows ==
The choir of the abbey includes 5 large stained glass windows designed by artist Marc Chagall and installed in 1970. Each of the 5 has a dominant color and depicts a Biblical story. From left (northern wall) to right, the 5 works are:

Prophets, depicting Elijah's ascent to heaven
Jacob, displaying his combat, and dreams of heaven
Christ, illustrating various scenes of Christ's life
Zion, showing an angel trumpeting the end of the world
Law, with Moses looking down upon the suffering of his peopleEqually impressive is the 9m tall stained glass of the North transept, created by Augusto Giacometti in 1940.


== Fraumünster's Crypt museum ==
Since the last renovation in 1900, the crypt under the choir of the Fraumünster abbey was sealed, and has made public since 19 June 2016. The oldest part of the church preserved the abbey's Holy Relics until the Reformation in Zürich banned the Roman Catholic adoration of saints. The foundations of the crypt date back to the 9th century when the abbey was founded. The crypt also comprises an exhibition on the history of the Reformation in Zürich, on the architecture and local history, assisted by a multimedia information system that illustrates the foundation fragments of the crypt, and how the church was rebuilt from the original Romanesque construction phase to its present Gothic appearance, on occasion of its establishment guided by Dölf Wild, the archaeologist in charge.


== Facilities ==
For the around 500,000 visitors every year a new developed visitor management started in June 2016. Visitors groups up to 60 persons are admitted from June 20 only by appointment and only in defined time windows. Guided tours are allowed only in a "whisper" modus, and by accredited tour guides, from 10 am to 4 pm in winter, and to 5 pm and 6 pm in spring respectively summer.


== The Organ ==

With 6.959 pipes, the organ at Fraumünster is the largest in the canton of Zurich.


== Gallery ==

		
		
		
		
		


== Abbesses ==
Hildegard (828-856 or 859), first abbess of Fraumünster Abbey
Katharina von Zimmern (1478-1547), last abbess of the Abbey


== Cultural heritage of national importance ==
In the Swiss inventory of cultural property of national and regional significance the Fraumünster is listed as a Class A object of national importance.


== Literature ==
Peter Vogelsanger: Zürich und sein Fraumünster. Eine elfhundertjährige Geschichte (853–1956). NZZ Libro, Zürich 1994, ISBN 3-85823-515-6


== See also ==
Grossmünster
Wasserkirche


== References ==


== External links ==
Official website

Jun 21: While walking around central Zurich, we came across Fraumunster Church - a lovely green/ mint coloured church which stands out with a clock. While we couldn’t go inside, from the outside, the beauty is hard to miss.

Inside are 5 beautiful Chagall stained glass windows that he made in the 1970s. Definitely worth the visit for those who like art. There is an entrance fee, and photos aren't allowed. There is also an old crypt area that has been partially excavated.

Please go and see the beautiful window paintings by Chagall, and remember to get a rebate on your entrance fee to Kunsthaus Zürich if you go there afterwards!
We didn't go in as it was closed. But I am sure the decorative stained glass windows would have been nice to see
The Chagall and Augusto Giacometti windows alone make it worthwhile to visit. The crypt is also interesting, with the ruiins of prior churches visible.
This is such a beautiful church. It’s famous because of the gorgeous windows of Chagall. It’s a must see.

Nice church and the view from the tower is quite impressive. I missed the no photo sign and the staff there (a guy) confronted me and lectured me despite me apologizing and deleting the photo in front of him. He just wouldn’t let it go and kept criticizing me until I was out of

It will cost adults 5 CHF. Children up to 16 years are free. It is the audio-guide in my opinion that makes the experience worth while. The audio-guide gives you information about the church, a select organ piece (Bach) from the 6959 pipe organ, a sample sermon, etc... The guide

Adults need to pay entrance fees to enter this church but it is absolutely worth it to see the spectacular windows designed by Marc Chagall. Entrance is free for children. One can visit the crypt to see the antique, centuries old, foundations. Photography is not permitted inside
Women are normally the least noticed, but Fraumunster puts women in a very favorable place. It's a timeless reminder that women are not an afterthought!
The best part of the church are the large Chagall windows, there are 5 beautiful windows in the abbey. Learning about the history of the history is also very enjoyable.

Fraumunster church is worth living if only for hte Chagal windows. But along with that there is the history of the church. Visit the "cellar" portion of the church which talks about how it was build on top of other foundations.
Part of the scenic city walkinh tour, get enthralled by the 17th century church with stained-glass windows designed by Chagall. There is an audio-story you could hear out about how it was done.

It's worth getting the audioguide and listening to the history of the Chagall windows. When we went (early) very few people were inside & it's nice sitting in the small area where the Chagall's are. Beautiful windows which tell interesting stories.
Learned a lot about the reformation and why the church was so stark and barren. Must pay to enter. Includes audioguide. No photos allowed.

We did the audio tour. The stained glass is beautiful. This place oozes history. Frankly compared to other European cities, zurich is a bit boring. This church was probably the most interesting place I saw

We were walking around the old town area and passed through this square with this church. Love the wooden door!

This along withGrossmunster , wonderful history beautiful architecture and history . An Abby run by the two daughters of king Ludwig .. I might be getting this mixed up with Fraumunster but they are both beautiful .

Fraumunster is the only one church in Zurich that I need to pay admission fee for entering. However I'd say it is worth the money. The church itself, the 5 large stained glass windows designed by artist Marc Chagall, and the wall paintings are all amazing to me. It's a must see

Everything great about the Grossmunster and its history is true, but this was our favorite church. The Fraumunster's architecture, history, windows and legend make it a great attraction and Zurich must see. First the building and steeple are simply amazing, sleek and delicate
The amazing stain glass, which were created by Chagall, make you want to sit quietly in the peace of this church. It was great to get out of the heat and tourist traffic and relax here.

The provided audio system was comprehensive and we spent longer here listening to the history of the building. Easy to access by public transport or walking across the bridge from the old town. Take the time to wander around this old area as well.

Best deal in Zurich! Take the audioguide tour for only 5 Francs and see the amazing Chagall windows in the church. The history of the church is very interesting too on the audioguide but the windows were one of the highlights of our whole trip. What a gem! Truly spectacular. Go

on the frontside of this church, there are some beautiful windows painted by Marc Chagall. unfortunately, access now is not free of charge anymore, but it is still worth to go in.
Beautiful church with traditional clock tower. It's by the river side and nearby Lake Zürich. It has a CHT 5 cost to enter.

For an entry fee of 5 CHF I thought there would be something unique inside. The audio guide helped in knowing the history. But I didn’t find anything exceptional. The outside premises of the Church is much better than the inside so the rating.

You don’t see a lot of churches charging an entry fee, but this one does. It is not very interesting compared to the many other churches in Europe. I’d skip it. It was just okay.
This is a modern architectural design church. The building is beautiful. The stained glass pretty.A good church to visit.

People told us we should visit the Fraumunster to see the windows by Marc Chagall. Those windows are beautiful, but there is so much more than that to see here. There is a 5CHF entrance fee, which is well worth paying. We recommend the audio guide instead of the written guide

It is an 11th century church. It used to be an abbey and you can see the aristocracy oozing... It is one of the prominent landmarks in and of Zurich. It is mostly known for it's glass windows. Very serene once inside.A must visit.

Unless you really love churches you can get a good view from the outside without paying. Eithier way you should visit.
Wonderful church, filled with History and art. Very nice audioguide that I recommend to catch the details. And amazing Chagall and Giacometti vitral works. Not to miss!

The entrance to the church is paid, so we decided to skip. Nowadays it is not possible to make everything be paid...

Worth the five Swiss francs to get in to see the stains glass designed by Marc Chagall. Really nice church that was once part of a convent.

My wife, son, daughter and I visited Fraumunster in Zurich in November 2018. The courtyards, small gardens and fountains were beautiful. Fraumunster is a "must-see" as you walk around the historical center of Zurich. I recommend getting a map of Zurich which will show you the
The magic of the church is in its surroundings and inside. An awesome home of God this church is truly divine

Went here with my father, came here 10 min before closing, and they let us in for free. The windows by Mark Chagall and Alberto Giacometti were amazing, and church overall was amazing. Would return 100 percent.
Fraumunster is a Zurich landmark situated right along the Limmat. The church itself is beautiful but the stained glass windows by Marc Chagall are the real draw.

This pretty little church is lovely. Of course it helps to have windows behind the altar by Marc Chagall. We didn’t go for services, just to look around. Underneath the altar is an old section that shows original excavation and other historic bits about the place. A nice visit.
This is definitely a major part of the landscape of Limmat. The green copper roof, and the design gives this place plenty of charm!
Most people visit here to see the Chagall windows, there is a charge to enter and photos are not allowed though you can buy merchandise. A pleasant enough Church you can find contemplation in.
This is a really attractive church with a beautiful blue Spire. There was a service on so inside you get the true atmosphere. Beside the river and a small square

A must see if you like Chagall - stunning, plus the church itself is nicely laid out and has interesting history for fans of church crawling.
When you know what precisely happened to this place and the other part at the other site of river,you can enjoy more.Recommend it to tourists.

Went to see the beautiful stained glass windows designed by Marc Chagall. They did now disappoint. Awe inspiring artistry was only added to by additional windows designed by Giacometti and the opportunity to walk through the crypt area with more history from the Reformation.

Good audio guide and pleasant place to spend an hour. The history is interesting and the Building well managed. I do not think they take credit cards, so bring local currency of €5 each. The Chagall windows are worth the visit alone.

It’s nice, it’s pretty, but after you take a photo you will be content and satisfied. I definitely wouldn’t plan on spending more than 20 minutes here. That would even be pushing it....
A quiet place for reflection and silence in the midst of busy city. The windows by Marc Chagall are stunning and definitely worth spending time looking at. Highly recommend on any trip to Zurich.

The amazing stained glass windows created by Chagall are worth the admission price. The free audio guide that is available makes the tour take a little less than an hour but brings out much rich history and detail that further enhance the visit. The explanation of the symbology
Right across the river from the more publicized Grossmuester Church. The stained glass is impressive and remarkable and there are postcards, bookmarks, posters etc. of the stained glass.
Just on the bank of Limmat, this nice old church is really charming. Pity that you are not allowed to take photos inside.
They now charge 5 each and there is no restroom. I think when they charge to see the church, they should provide a restroom! The small museum in the basement was interesting.
Chagall's windows at this church are stunning and definitely worth the 20-30 minutes of your time. The church itself is plain but the stained glass here is lovely.

I guess this place may be worth it to have to PAY 5 francs to get inside... and then they ban you from taking pictures on the inside??? Sorry...I took a few shots of the outside and that will be it. (Does it cost 5 francs if you want to go inside to pray?) Not worth it.

A lovely church, but being unable to take photos is such a shame when there is only a very limited display of postcards on offer! However make sure you take advantage of the free audio guide as it is both interesting and well explained.
Beautiful church. Too bad you cannot take any pictures, unlike other churches in Europe where you can. Bells are beautiful and the gold really stands out on the tower.

The Fraumünster (Women's Minster) Church with its famous blue-spire and breathtaking stained-glass windows created by the famed artist Marc Chagall are its USP. A must go place if you are interested in art.

Nice, but not magnificent church with a number of nice touches, most of all windows by Marc Chagall that make it worth a visit if you are in or near Zurich.Chagall is my favorite artist and I am especially fond of his windows. The color, the exubrance, the bizarreness ( is
This is a lovely big cathedral, but there is a cost to enter, which is sad on churches. we just stuck our heads in the door for a quick peek, as found that 7 euros was a bit steep.

I had an extra day in Zurich so I explored old town. Fraumunster church was easily recognizable by its clock tower. I found the church a little disappointing, as much of its old art had been removed during the reformation period. The Chagall windows are worth viewing, as they
5chf entrance to visit the church that has beautiful stained glass windows and organ. Plus a crypt with ruins underneath. Good activity for 30-40minutes. No photos allowed inside
For 5 franc you get history and artistic beauty. An audio tour is included and is highly recommended for all the information that it imparts. The Chagall windows are defintiely worth seeing.

The magnificent stained glass windows by Marc Chagall are one of the many reasons to visit the Fraumunster Church. His use of colour is sublime. You can sit quietly and take in the shades of green, blue and yellow with their religious themes. The crypt is another worthwhile

This small church provides a well organized and substantial audio tour that builds up to the shockingly beautiful windows over the choir of the church. Note, no photos are allowed, but there is a small gift area by the exit with bookmarks, cards, and a few photo posters. This
nice peaceful church with no frills and very quiet and peaceful , also not very touristy place but good to visit

Zurich has several great churches, but this is my favourite, mostly for the crypt below the church itself and also of the incredible stained glass windows on display inside. Entry is 5 francs, which is very reasonable.

I did have a great time there. You can chose an audio guide or brochure with your ticket. I am glad I did chose an audio guide. There was lots of infos about history of this church and the most important stained glass windows created by Marc Chagall. The interior design of this

The Fraumunster is one of the oldest religious buildings dating back to 853 AD. The now simply decorated Protestant church has beautiful stained glass windows by Chagall and Giacometti. Mary's Chapel has the only remaining examples of early art. No photos allowed! The price of
Beautiful austere church with magnificent stained glass windows and a large church organ. Many windows by Marc Chagall made in his later years with striking colors and stories of the Bible.

I have been fortunate to have visited this lovely church with its special stained glass windows by Chagall and Giacometti on several occasions. It never fails to impress. The cost is minimal at Chf 5 from memory. With that we had a detailed audio guide. One inspiring piece of
This church is absolutely worth checking out even if you aren’t looking for Jesus. The stained glass work by Chagall is incredible!

This church is still very active. The entrance fee is minimal, but you cannot take any pictures, even without the flash. They give you an individual audio guide which is thorough. Also, a booklet with a picture of the windows is for you to keep. After seeing a lot of
This is a cool place with a lot of rich history. But the reason you must go is those incredible Chagall windows. Oh, my!
This church is really worth a visit. Outstanding stained glass windows in the Church by Chagall. Beautiful Church with a great walking tour explaining the significant art work.
The stain glass windows by Chagall is worth spending time enjoying but the church itself is very lovely.

We tried to see the church twice. The first time it was 4:00 and they were closed even though everything (including signs on the church) says they are open to 6:00. The second time we got there at 1:40 to find out they were closing at 2:00. They let us in but wouldn't let us use
We had to pay to enter but it was free for the kids. At 5 CHF, you get an audio guide as well. Worth a visit if you have time.

We spent a peacefl hour here and rented the listening device that explained the beautiful windows, organ and church design. The explanations of these can best be understood with the use of the audio guide that is available in many languages. Definitely a place not to be missed.
If you are a history buff or a fan of Chagal Glass, see it. If not, skip this one as there is an entrance fee 5SF pp and to me, it wasn’t worth it.

If u have been to rome or any other places with nice basilicas , don’t waste time coming to this church.. absolutely nothing special inside although the facade looks nice... no need to waste 5 franc to enter.. i came out of it within 5 mins

Easy walk from train station, with great siteseeing along the way. Church now charges to enter. Make your visit as part of other nearby local attractions. River walk, the Bahnhofsstrasse, Europe’s most expensive shopping street, etc. Unless you feel the need for a group

This church is a must see for art lovers, you will not see another church with stained glass windows from Chagall and Giacometti. Other than that the crypt is interesting, and the organ is nice too although we didn't hear it while visiting. Entrance is 5CHF with audioguide
There are many more ornate cathedrals in Europe than this, but the windows by Chagall are beautiful and the audio guide is quite well done.

Fraumunster was a monastery for noble women. The church is stripped of pictures, altars, statues because it was felt that these served as distractions. The pulpit is large, elevated and central to the church because the word of God is central to faith. The stained glass
The audio tour is very knowledgeable. Its a good idea to sit down and listen to the history of this place. Must do.
The Chagall windows are breathtaking. Be sure to ask for an audio guide to get the utmost information. Beautiful church with an unbelievable history.
This church has been built and rebuilt throughout the ages. Audio available with entry fee. No photos. Chagall windows are interesting. Crypt has architectural interest.

There was a line of people to get in and we didn't understand why there was a line. We walked a little closer and saw there was a 5 CHF or €5 charge per person to enter and we refuse to pay to enter any church so we walked away. A few steps down we could see a wedding taking

It's so incredible what humans did without the technology we have today. This was built in 836!!! Take the self-guided audio tour. You get a headset and device to listen and wander through the church. We got into and enjoyed the awe and quiet sanctity of the place until a tour

In the 1970s, Marc Chagall was commissioned to create a series of windows for the Fraumünster's "choir," that is, the space behind the altar, which is really like a separate raised chapel within the church. Be sure to see these tall, narrow windows on a sunny day. They just glow

We went to Zurich with no master plan but rather the intention to wander about and take it all in. We found Fraumünster during our meandering and decided to go inside. It’s a few francs and we decided to opt for the audio tour, which I’m so happy we did. It was really

The Chagall windows in the charming church are a must see. The history and story behind them is amazing. The windows are not the only aspect of this church that makes it so interesting. It's own history is remarkable. Easy to get to and an inexpensive entrance fee.

We really enjoyed our visit to the Fraumunster Cathedral. The Chagall stained glass windows are beautiful. Take the time to see them. The stories in the stained glass are remarkable. Well worth the visit.
Beautiful Chegal windows , quite remarkable to see the past history of the building , would recommend a visit
The Chagall windows in this church are a must see for Zurich. Try to go in the morning, when the light comes through the windows.
There are three groupings of painted stained glass windows by Marc Chagall as only he can do them. Depictions of both old and new testament scenes. Also an Alberto Giacometti window.

The English audio tour guide equipment can be rent at the entrance, it gave you all the story behind each windows and the whole history of the church. If you are visiting, renting the audio tour guide is a better option!

We went back to the church as it was closed for the morning. Unfortunately they only take cash and as it was our last day we were all out. The outside courtyard however was really worth a visit with wonderful medieval murals

Worth going into the church and paying for an audio guide (about 5 euros), as it provide a good history of the church/religion in Zurich. The audio guide had some talks on the art/interpretation of the stain glass windows which was a bit boring (i'm not into art). The church
Zürich is full of protostantic churches which can be visited for small donations but with different architecture than classic catholic church
We had a long walk by the lake and we visited this beautiful church with a great architectural design.
The inside of the church is so lovely. The outside delicate copper topped spire is stained by the famous painter Mark Chagall. You will have a lovely quality time
Chagall windows, Cherub fountains, fascinating atmosphere of Old Europe. Belongs in every European traveler's bucket list.

Before traveling to Zurtich, we had not known of the Chagall stained glass windows at Fraumunster. Among the most beautiful Chagalls we have seen. Well worth spending an hour on a sunny day (so there is good ight through the windows). I recommend the audio tour - and I
The famous Chagall windows are the top attraction of this church and are really worth the visit. The rest of the church is less impressive, but overall still worthwhile to spend some 45 min here.

Graumunster church is also called as the Womens Church, is one of the four main churches in Zurich. The panoramic view of the clock tower is beautiful from the near by bridge and the view of this church is good from the Grossmunster church across the river. The stained glass
This church is 5 CHF to visit. It's pretty plain inside but is well worth a visit if you like the architecture. Nice area too.

This church has been on my mind ever since I paid a visit (from outside) last year as this was the ONLY church I encountered with a compulsory entry fee right at the door, in our entire Europe trip. The other churches you could enter and then opt for your paid tour in detail if

Free entrance is unfortunately passé - you now have to pay a - relatively small - fee to enter and visit the church. Quite a disappointment at a time where it gets very difficult to still do things 'for free'.
Looks very nice , I did not go inside. I saw it while my tour in the old city. Near by there are many restaurant , no blue parking availiable , only white parking which is for local.
One of the three most famous churches in oldtown of zurich. A 13 century church famous for its stained glass window..

I wasn't as impressed by the windows inside as I had expected to be. It is a pretty church but not quite the standout that I expected. It is also the only church in Switzerland that I had to pay to enter other than to climb a tower. It is also the only to ban photos inside.
Beautiful church, some great pictures of this church can also be taken from Grossmünster tower. Must see in Zurich.
Beautiful place to visit while your on vacation! I did city your! It's very wonderful to visited church while your on vacation to thank god!
A 5CHF entry fee with an excellent audio guide describing in details the history of the church and interpretation of Chagall's stained glass windows.

A beautiful historic site whose history is intertwined with the city of Zurich. If you are a history buff, this is a must to visit. It is important for art lovers as well. The stained glass by Marc Chagall is stunning. For 5 Swiss francs you get a set of head phones and a
What a gorgeous church that has beautiful stained glass windows done in the 1970's. Went through the church with my private guide, Patrick, who I will request again when I return to Zurich! DO THIS!
What a beautiful place, great location, a must visit, amazing, next to the water, lots of activities to do around.

This is a lovely building with an interesting history. The stained glass windows are sensational. We missed out on concert opportunities but would definitely try to do that if in Zurich again as the acoustics must be glorious.

First, an apology if you are following my posts. I mistakenly posted on the grossmunster about the chagall windows. Wrong church (a little confused after these weeks bouncing around Europe). The famed Chagall windows are in this church. As to the windows, we have seen more
