The church is very nice and simple. Impersive Chagall vitrals and history itself. you can attend concerts too.

The Fraumunster in Zurich is a protestant church that is full of history. It also has five beautiful stained glass windows designed by artist Marc Chagall and installed in 1970, which are well worth seeing. Equally impressive is the tall stained glass window created by Augusto
Legends, history, political power, and beautiful stained glass windows are all a part of this lovely church. It was a must see in Zurich.
i just wondering they said about thiz church... so i decided to drop by to see it by my self and it was really nice. i love church so i suggest that visitor must see this holy place at all..

We learned about the history of this church while taking the free walking tour of Zurich and thought we should go back to see the Chagall stained glass windows. The windows are nice to see - the description of what is going on in each window is a little hard to follow. Worth
Of course you must visit this church when visiting Zurich. It is beautiful and one of the great churches in Europe.

I wandered into this church and decided to go ahead and spend the 5 Swiss francs for the admission. I'm so glad I did. The Marc Chagall stain glass windows are worth the price alone. Get the audio guide to hear about the interpretation. There are 5 tall, skinny windows

This church is getting a lot of attention these days due to all the Asian fans of Chagall. The stain-class altar windows are beautiful and they offer a very good audio guide, included in the price. It is worth a visit.

The Chagall windows are the best ever and really need to be studied with all of the hidden meanings Scheduled a 200 mile trip just to see them again Low entry fee Old windows of classic style are worth the visit also

Was there in 1971 and remembered the Chagall windows. Made a special two day trip from Basel just to do it again. Nice quiet church. Can buy tickets at lobby. NO PHOTOS!!! Need to have a great memory. In the area, go. These windows are unique and spectacular

Another austere Protestant church but worth the visit for it's history (formerly an Abbey and, of course, Catholic). It has five Chagall stained glass windows that are brilliant and also one by Giacometti. The best church to visit in Zurich.
The church is not very impressive, but it has vitraux from Chagall and that is worth seeing. Also has vitraux from an italian artist, which are very good too.

Rather a plain church apart from the radiant colours of the Chagall windows in his unmistakeable style. The dream like imagery is captured in glass. Easier to read than the Giacometti windows which are very dark.
I was surprised to be charged 5 francs to enter a church but it was well worth it! The magnificence and beauty of Chagalls stained glass windows were Awesome!

The church itself is rather sparse, though it does seem to have played a relatively important role in the history of Zurich and the area. There's a very small exhibit in the crypt talking about this - the crypt is actually foundations of what once might have been a crypt. For
Free tour in the church with the help of the audio recording explaining the history of this church and the meaningful paintings all around. Marc chagals' colored windows left me breathless!

If you like Chagall - visit this church!! They charge an entry fee, which I felt was totally worth it to view the beautiful stained glass windows from inside. We stayed about an hour, which is quite long for what there is. We ended up sitting down and just enjoying the view.
This is a very old church with history dating back prior to the 1400's. There is an audioguide which is great and guides you through each area. Amazing history.
Quite steep for the price to enter. Best to just learn about the history the church and check the surroundings and skip going inside.

Next to the City Hall and a small stroke from Paradeplatz, the banking center of Zurich, the Fraumuenster is manly famous for the huge Chagall stained windows and the magnificent organ. that alone is worth peeping in, but if you are lucky, you can join a great concert usually

Most churches in Switzerland are free. Not this one. Don't pay to go in, it's a rip off. Take photos outside. To go in will cost you 5 CHF (basically $5) per person AND they don't allow photos AND they won't let you use the bathroom. We figured for $10 they should have a

This year you have to pay to get inside the church ! Wow! Most people want to have a look at the windows, painted by Chagall. Those were given to the church for FREE! So, how fair is it to charge 5 francs?! to get inside the church? The windows are absolutely gorgeous! A must to
The Chagall windows were colorful and amazing! Wished I could stay longer. And wished taking pictures were allowed.
Visited this church our trip to Switzerland. The church is pretty to see from the outside but on the inside it is very basic. Even though you’ll need to give it a visit when going to this place.

Across the bridge after visiting the Grossmunster, you will see the single blue green spire of the Fraumunster. It was originally a convent in the 9th century. It became a church in 1250 until the Reformation in 1524 transformed the church into a Protestant place of worship.

A plain church which became Protestant after nearly 700 years. It's instructive to compare it with the Benedictine Catholic baroque monastery at Eisiedeln - particularly the pulpit. The Chagall windows are, to say the least, colourful - though somewhat abstract, and the museum
Switzerland seems to have a lot of churches. If you need to select one to visit, this might be your best beet as it has some beautiful glass work by arc Chagall. Entry 5 EUR/CHF/USD.

The Fraumünster Church was built on the remains of a former abbey for aristocratic women founded in 853 by Louis the German for his daughter Hildegard. It houses the Chagall windows, which depict five biblical stories.

Chagell is special and always worth a look. Staff were very friendly and nice to have a look round. Still don't like having to pay to enter a church. Donations yes. Pay no especially as the Windows were gifted to the church. Hence 3 not 4 starts.
We were lucky enough to be there on a Thursday when they offer a free organ recital at noon - at least through to the end of September. Wonderful sound and a way to see the Chagall windows for free.

This lovely former convent church is fairly simply decorated, except for the modern stained glass. Definitely use the audio guide included with t he price of admission, to learn about the history and various architectural features of the building. Then sit and enjoy the

Entry includes an audio guide which really brings the history of this building to life. Walk around at your leisure being directed to look where you might not otherwise and learn interesting stories behind the structure.
It is always nice to see a bit of history and walk through a church, in any city you visit. However, I am not fond of the 5 CHF charge they have for the visit.

If you are into history of course you must visit. Every city if there is a church I will always visit and say a thankful prayer or two and then enjoy whatever else I do. Inside is nice, peaceful and calming. Do try to visit

The windows done by Chagall are amazing! But... I felt very weird to pay the entrance fee to get in. It is only 5 francs, but the fact that you have to pay to see the church is very strange for me. Still do go there to see the windows, but keep in mind that it is paid.
The Chagall's are spectacular. You cannot see the stain glass colours from the outside but once you enter and the organ is playing the stain glass hits you with an 'Ah ha' moment.
Must see place to visit whilst strolling around downtown Zurich. Wonderful interior inside. Have to pay some entry fees to enter but worth it.

This Church is one of the main features to visit whilst strolling around downtown Zurich . It is located between Bahnhofstrasse and the old city The main reason to visit is to sit and contemplate whilst gazing at the stained-glass windows by Chagall. Even if you are

This lovely church which was founded as a convent in 853 and was for many centuries and Benedictine Convent until the Reformation. The actual Church interior is simple and plain, but with amazing Chagal Windows from the 1970s. The exterior and cloisters and lovely and

Entry is free for children. Adults pay 5 CHF each. You can choose between an audio guide or a brochure. We choose both. The 5 large stained glass windows designed by Marc Chagall are stunning. You are not allowed to take photos inside the church.
What I have noticed it is that people who are in the church ( not the church clergy)do not welcome tourists. For me this has happened only in Switzerland.
Windows painted by Marc Chagall. Very good audioguides that explain everything about the artist's intent.
Would deinitely recommend the audio tour of this church - which focused on the stained glass windows by renowned artist Marc Chagall.

A church or historic site is my question. I believe it to be a historic site since they asked us to pay 5chf per head. Some very well preserved history. The stain glass art was very impressive considering the age. You are not allowed to take photos inside so sorry.

Marc Chagall is my favorite artist. I had a 5 hour layover in Zurich, so I was excited to see this church that had his stained glass artwork. It was mesmerizing sight to see. I will always cherish seeing his work in person. Not only was seeing Chagall's work amazing...
This church is home to the beautiful stained glass windows by Marc Chagal. The church itself is peaceful and quiet. The day we visited there was an organ concert.

The audio guide is very informative. This church has existed from 800 AD. Was impressed by my first exposure to Zurich's role in the Reformation movement. Interesting to hear about the efforts of Zwingli and Pastor Ulrich esp considering that in their days their theories would

Beautiful old church in the heart of the Old Town in beautiful Zürich! I would highly recommend visiting and paying the small amount to go inside and see the amazing architecture and of course, the colorful and amazingly beautiful stain glass windows. Doesn't take a lot of time

Usually I object paying entry fees for a church but in this case the 5 francs is well worth it. You get an audio guide that takes you through the features of the building and the basics of Protestantism. The stained glass Windows alone are worth the entry fee.

It was recommended to me that I visit the Fraumunster while in Zurich. This large church and its twin across the river dominate the landscape and jointly make for a great photo of the Old Town. This former convent church was disappointing when first entering, as it had been

For a 5CHF donation we entered the church and immediately saw what everyone talks about- the Chagall windows. It was a sunny day and the light streaming through was wonderful. There is a lot to look at apart from just the windows and the crypt museum is worth seeing as well as

This is very nice protestant church so you should not expect to see a beautiful decor inside of it. But the main decoration inside is famous stained glass windows designed and made by Marc Chagall. They really worth of seeing. The entrance fee is 5chf and audio guide is offered

It's not so much the church but, rather, the Chagall windows and the one by Giacometti. There's a small entry fee now but the set up is worth the expense. Enjoy the windows; Chagall created them for a princely sum later in life. They're amazing. I could sit there all day. Also
Here are the famous Chagal windows - we were privileged to view them and not just in a book. Very interesting architecture.

Just walking around Zurich town and their alley's we come across this place and it is good for photo ops. There are some painting that looks faded to my views but when I see it enlarge it shows some colors and I was surprised I didn't expect it, really :)

Honestly this church did not have anything of great interest and I spent very little time here. The history of the church is interesting but there isn't really anything about it in the church. I was also underwhelmed by the stained glass windows which are mean to be well-known,

The not to be missed element of this church is the Chagall Windows, 5 of them, 30 feet high created by Chagall in his 80s as the backdrop of the altar. Excellent audio guide available and explains the blending of the Jewish and Christian symbols.

We so enjoyed our audio tour of Frauminister. The Chagall windows are beautiful and were our reason for coming here. But we loved learning about the history of this church as well as its beautiful windows. Make it a stop on a trip to Zurich!

This may be the prettiest cathedral in Zurich if not Switzerland. Combination of old/new art and architecture. The Chagall Stained Glass windows are a site to behold (Make sure you look at side window views). Light and Airy, visit Crypt and walk around. Nicely located near the

We had only an afternoon in Zurich and were so glad to make it here. I had never heard of the Chagall windows before reading a Zurich guidebook and cannot believe it now. Both my friend and I were brought to tears just sitting and looking at the windows. The rest of the church
This is a gem in the city of Zurich. The Chagall windows are beautiful as are the other stained glass windows.
For church lovers its worth a visit as its well maintained and has wonderful stained glass windows by Chagall.Church is quite plain inside but the windows are great. Beautiful blues.

I have always enjoyed visiting churches and other religious sites on my travels. The church itself, while very historical, is very plain in the Swiss Reformation style, with the exception of the Chagal windows in the Nave. When we got to them, I sat and just stared in awe at

The audio guide assists understanding this beautiful church's history. The feature is the stained glass windows and they have a history too. Using the audio guide, allow an hour to enjoy this site.
A Protestant New Testament Church showcasing Old Testament beautiful windows designed by the famous Jewish artist Chagall. If you see nothing else in Zurich you must see these windows

A church with a great history and nice architecture. It is opposite the old town and just behind it is the high end shopping belt.
Although admission is not free, it was a nice place to visit to appreciate the famous stained glass windows inside the church sanctuary. Good respite from the summer heat outside!
Was able to see this pretty church from the outside only . came as part of a tour on the Zurich city tour. Gorgeous architecture that you can stop and look at if you are in the area.

We spent the 5 francs to go inside and it was a nice quiet break and a chance to see a beautiful church. The stained glass windows are the highlight, but the free audio guide also gives a nice history of the church and its role in the Reformation. It is right across the river
I have a friend who lives in Zürich she told me I should visit this wonderful Church. İt has Marc Chagall's vitraux in it. You have to take tickets (10 Frank each person)

the windows in this small church are a must see. in oldtown and nearby shops and restaurants are great.
We were only able to see the church from the outside as when we reached there it had already closed at 5 pm around. But it was beautiful from outside very different architecture.
We came to see the stained glass windows by Marc Chagall and they were wonderful. The audio guide had very good information on it.
Beautiful. Chigall windows. Interesting history. Entrance was 5CF/PP but came with headset in your language.
The church interior is fairly plain. The Marc Chagall stained glass windows are definitely the drawing point. Each of the windows was a different color. Photos are not allowed.
It's worth to take the audio guide included in the entrance fee to listen to the description of the church, especially the stained glass of Chagall.
And also Grossmünster church .. 2 churchs Photos were prohibited instead coz there r some works there made by Chagall .. so u can imagine...

we visited several churches all within walking distance of one another , Inquire about the operational hours as they do fluctuate from season to season . This can all be done in less than 6 hours walking and sight seeing
Another european church. The original architecture is from the alps but insides is a regular one. If you do not go or get inside it is ok. And if you do, it is ok too.
Only seen it from the outside didn't get a chance to go inside but definitely looks nice from the outside, very good for photo opportunities especially on sunset
Premier site to visit in Zurich. Magnificent windows otherwise stark interior. Entry fee (I think 5 Swiss fr--paid by tour so don't know for sure)

This church has been here for centuries and has weathered the changes from being a Catholic nunnery to a Protestant church. The church features beautiful stained glass windows by the artist, Marc Chagall and the crypt offers an interesting peak into the history of the area.
As with most of the other churches, didn't get a chance to go inside. But you can't miss it, it stands out when in Zurich and is great for photos.
Not just another church...like I thought. Very interesting little place with interesting history. Story of the stained glass maker/artist was an unexpected surprise and glass was beautiful.
Was an ok way to spend a cold and rainy afternoon. Entrance fee of CHF5 was reasonable. Best part was the crypt. Stained glass windows were all from the 20th Century. No pics allowed.
Beautiful temple and i am happy that i have visited it. At the center of the town. Outside there are very beautiful wall paintings and they are like alive.

The Church is famous for its history and celebrated glasses windows from Chagall and Giacometti. The entrance fee should imply that you could then enjoy the church itself without furhter worries. Yet it is strictly forbidden to take photos and films...just to try forcing
Well worth a visit to see the stained glass by Chagall and Giacometti. Good audio guide. NO photography.
Very interesting to listen to the stories, allow at least 1 hour for the visit and Chagall's mosaics is incredible!

The history of this church is fascinating. Thankfully, the small history display in the crypt helps you understand the development of the church in that location over time; useful if you choose to not get a free (with your 5 euro entrance) audio tour. The Chagall windows

The Fraumunster is one of the oldest religious building in Zurich. For many centuries it was a Benedictine convent, but with the Reformation, the abbey and all its assets were handed over to the city of Zurich. The church is noted for its austerity, as compared to the old
Good paintings Great design I have enjoyed it personally although I am not christian Won’t recommend a lot of time for the visit

It's a beautiful church with great stained glass windows. Outside the church you can have lunch at one of the old guild houses that has been converted into a cafe. It's a great experience, sitting there outside having lunch on a suuny day in the spring.

If there is time for only one church visit in Zurich this is the place to go. The audio self guided tour is well worth the SF5.0 entry fee. The stained glass windows are spectacular. The history of the place is incredible. You can spend a few hours here and not even notice the

This church is beautiful and even better kept. The surrounding area is nicely kept and there are plenty of placards informing tourists about elements of the church. Be sure to walk in the grotto where the ornate frescos and statues are breathtaking.

Upon entrance you will be asked to pay admission of 5 CHF which roughly is 5 USD (per person)! Me and my girlfriend paused in surprise and then turn back and left... We visited many many churches and cathedrals and usually donate. But this was mandatory, which we found
Fraumünster is a church which was belonged to ladies as it is clear from it's name. While we were visiting old town the church was not open so we just took a look of outside of the church.
What a beautiful building. Very simple inside, calm and spiritual. Stained glass windows are amazing. Inexpensive to get in.
The Marc Chagall windows are far to see from the church's floor but if you take photos and enlarge you will see the fine details.

Had visited Fraumunster while in Zurich for a about 6 hours and this place is simple amazing and picturesque to say the least. The view from the river bridge of the city is simply amazing . A must visit for someone visiting Zurich.

Do not miss seeing the windows in this church. There are 5 Marc Chagall in the choir area, 1 rose window on a side wall, and 1 window by Giacometti on the opposite wall. Breathtaking. We had no idea this was in Zurich. This surely was a thrill.

One of the old churches at the heart of Zurich. Probably the one must-see sight I encountered. The modern stained glass windows are beautiful. The museum in the crypt is very helpful in understanding the history of Zurich and the Swiss Reformation. Well worth the CHF 5 admission

The architecture of the church and others like it in Zurich is a must see when you are in Zurich. It was not very busy when we went there but at times it seems there are tour groups that go past so it might get busy later in the day.

The Fraumunster is one of the four Zurich main cathedral/churches that are noticeable in the skyline. It is located on the southern/eastern side of the Lemmat. As you walk around the Old Town streets you will eventually find it and can see it close-up. It has a large courtyard

The city of Zurich has many clock towers, we stumbled upon this one which looked great. Took many photos, it is a great tourist attraction.

They don't allow photography and they also charge an entrance fee, which appeared to include an audio tour. Now, here's my problem with that mess: I will donate to a church of I am allowed to come inside and pray, admire and learn. I will not pay a cent to get an audio tour, not

The Fraumunster is a beautiful small church along the Limmat River. The spire with its mock gabled roof surrounding the clock is a landmark of the city. We ate dinner at a restaurant across the river and enjoyed looking at the illuminated church and listening to the bells.

Nice place to visit. Quite quiet, so a nice good place to sit down and reflect. And think about the worldly things you want to explore at night.
Very beautiful Church at the nice location, we didn't get to go inside as it was closed while we were around, looks beautiful from outside as well.
The church is gorgeous: it has gothic and romanesque parts and the highlight are the beautiful windows by Chagall.
Europe has numerous historic churches. If you enjoy seeing them, this should be one of them. Great views in a walk friendly area.

We took a guide and embarked on a visit of the Reformation churches. Just walk along the Limmat river, you can spot churches by their high towers. Went in , had a look at the statue of abbess Katharina von Zimmern, the organ, the stained glass windows. Peaceful, calm , serene.
Had a lovely visit here, great place to take photos. Beautiful views of stained glass windows to see.
It is a former abbey for aristocratic women which was founded in 853 by Louis the German for his daughter Hildegard. You must visite it for 5 wonderful stained glass of Chagall.

This church has an iconic green-topped clock tower with an exquisite, large clock face. It has some gorgeous stained glass windows--at least one by Mark Chagall. In close proximity to many notable Swiss landmarks and the river.

It is a wonderful church and too beautiful. it is a must for history and architecture enthusiasts but i would recommend it to everyone
A wonderful church with unique Chagall windows. Christmas mass is charming. The church as a beautiful organ.
If you enjoy history and old architecture then it is worth a visit. Beautiful inside. Gorgeous stain glass windows.

We planned for Zurich day trip and Fraumunster Church was one of the place we decided to visit on that day. The church is very close to train station and is at walk-able distance from other places of interest like Lindenhof Park, Bahnhofstrasse and old town The Church is famous
Formerly an abbey! Today a protestant church, which is famous for its windows designed by Chagall. Absolutely worth visiting...
Came to a Christmas concert with the family. Beautiful church right next to the lake. Amazing concert and the church is close to shops and restaurants. Highly recommend to visit.

The Chagall windows are stunning. Great to sit and contemplate them. The crypt below was lovely too.

Just sit and stare at the astonishing Chagall stained glass windows. This church is by far the most beautiful church I've ever seen! The simplicity of the church adds to the beauty of the jewels that it holds! We were not asked to pay an admission fee.
The church form the outside is still an inspiring looking church. When you are inside the stain glass windows are spectacular and well worth the admission price.

Almost an embarrassment of riches with 6 Chagall stained-glass windows and a large Giacometti window. Stunning! There is a 5 euro admission fee but it comes with a short guide which helps to explain the history of the church and the windows. There are no restrooms on site.

Strolling down the classy and chic Bahnhofstrasse, turn right into Poststrasse and catch the first glimpse of a quintessential Zurich landmark, the pointy-headed clock tower of the Fraumünster Church.

I visited in a Sunday to see the stained glass windows by Chagall. I thought Sunday was a good day to visit as long as I didn't go in while a service was taking place. I entered the lobby and was told entry cost CHF5.00. On a Sunday! Instead I admired the banners, which are
Very interesting church by river with fantastic Mark Chagal glass windows a must to see when you visit Zurich
Sort time ago, this church is asking for a CHF 5.- entrance fee. It's unbelievable, even for Zürich citizens and residents, attending this church quite often.

The highlights of the church are the vitraux that Chagall made in old age. Also there is vitraux that is made by Giacometti

It is worth the price to enter this church and admire the windows by Chagall and by Giacometti. We did not take the audio.

As active members of our local church, we visit many churches in our travels. We both appreciate Impressionist art being regulars at Musée d'Orsay. So on our 1st visit together to Zurich we were disappointed that the Fraumunster was closed to visitors when we got there. This
I had passed the Fraumünster and went back because me travel guide recommended to see the stained glass windows. Contrary to outdated advice they are charging 2 CHF now for admission.
We came across Fraumunster as part of our Old Town walk. The clock is beautiful. Unfortunately, we did not enter the church.
looks nice from outside but overall not enjoyable. Will not visit again if I visitef Zurich in the future.

The entrance fee to the church is 2 CHF. Beautiful interior. A very distinct church which I have seen in Europe. Chagall windows are beautiful. The church is in the heart of the city from where St. Peter's Church & Grossmunster is also nearby.

This place is centrally located next to the Limmat River.. gives an overview of old European architecture.. have a lot of restaurants around the place too.. the lights come out in the night which makes it very good..

What a gift to have been so close to this gem. The beautiful Chagall artwork in the windows is breathtaking! It was serene in it's own beauty to sit and reflect.
Normally open to the public but we had it to ourselves for a wedding. The whole atmosphere was excellent but the stained glass windows, one by Chagall, were superb.
One of the oldest churches in Zurich builded for the noble ladies.You have to visit it to adore the works of Chagal and Giacometti

The Fraumunster ,one of the oldest religious buildings in Zurich,was founded in 853,as a Benedictine convent.There are stained glass windows by Marc Chagall in the chancel and south transept end Giacometti in north transept.
The five windows by Chagall are beautiful and the main reason for the visit to this church. No photos are allowed unfortunately so sit and enjoy this artwork for as long as you need.
The Reformation severely damaged some beautiful buildings and this is a good example of how to convert a beautiful house of God into a large undistinguished place
This is heaven ,i have not seen such a heavenly place in my life ever,beautiful place,light music by side.Great lake view,cafe by side.
Church has stained glass windows by Chagall. Worth a visit, there is an entrance fee. Lots of history in the area

This Church was very busy when we stopped by with very large tour groups. Again another very fine Church building right in the heart of the old town. Well worth a viewing.
Just saw it from outside its beautiful. Did not go in. Good place to get pictures taken and also just relaxing on the outside. Its an open space where people just walk and take pictures

The history of this place is very impressive and the windows are a must. From the outside they look like normal church windows but inside, on a sunny day...beautiful. Worth paying the 2 frans.

Great stain glass windows and beautiful exterior as well with the clock tower and oxidised green look. The walls are beautifully decorated too with different stories so it's very interesting.

I try not to miss a few quiet moments in Fraumunster whenever I am in Zurich, however briefly. It is a visual treat just to sit in the small chapel where the hushed atmosphere affords itself to moments of meditation. It truly refreshed your spirit.
This is a beautiful church from 1732 with beautiful windows by Marc Chagall. You can't take pictures but it's worth stopping in

Went to see the Chagall Windows, amazing, the architecture and renovations done over the years retain the beauty of this building.

The stained glass by Chagall was beautiful and you can sit and admire them as long as you wish. It is a shame that churches ask you to pay to enter - which they here called a donation but was actaully mandatory - but it was only 2CHF each and was worth it to see the stained

The church is in the midst of a square and one was taken aback by the 2 franc charge to begin with. However once inside it was breathtakingly beautiful. The Marc Chagall windows made the interior of the church just so much different.
Nice church with beautiful stained glass. Requested 2 Swiss francs per person for entry, definitely worth the price of entry.
We loved seeing the beautiful Marc Chagall windows at the Fraumunster Church in Zurich. They are just amazing.

The church is extremely beautiful and well renovated. The view outside is also so nice. If you want to buy souvenirs this is an affordable place to buy them. You can get souvenirs for both the Grossmünster and this church there.
The glass windows made according to the plans of Marc Chagall are absolutely worth a visit. Take your time and immerse into the many stories he is telling in his typical colours.
Went today and thoroughly enjoyed it. Surprised other reviewers have a problem with paying 2 francs. Paid 5 francs for a bottle of water on the street. Now that is a rip off!

The Church is nice but before you get to enter the church you are asked to make a donation of 2francs per person then they let you into the church. They only do this to the tourists. This church is free.

One of Zurich's oldest churchs. Great stained glass windows, a crypt and great architecture. Some great surrounding buildings and sights if you take a quick walk around its outsides.

The Church of Fraumunster is an obligatory passage location. Take the opportunity to enter the church if you have access or enjoy taking pictures of this magnificent monument. recommend

If there is one church to visit in Zurich it is most certainly this one. It is located across from the larger church but the stained glass windows make it a must! The square where it is located, is also very picturesque with many choices for outdoor dining.
Big church but a bit bare inside. Stained glass windows are nice. It is amazingly cool inside inspite of the absemce of A/c

This is amazing church! Please pop in for a quick relax time with a view that is going to take your breath away! Chagalls glass windows are something you really need to see for yourself to understand the beauty of those.

One of the main sights in town and a landmark for orientating yourself around town. Worth popping in just to see the 5 Chagall stained glass windows. Really unique !! The church organ is also impressive. It will be on your way so pop in !
Astonishing windows and architecture. Really worth a trip. Depending on your interest you can plan from 10 min up to hours for this attraction

Outside looks good but inside is repaired. It is full of historic stories. But it is small and simple.

The windows are an attraction for me every time I visit Zurich. The square adjacent to the church is also very lovely. Not to be missed.

Smaller than the Munster but the stained glass window in this church are works of art in their own right.
This is a lovely little square overlooking the city. It has ancient roots. It is a bit of a walk uphill, but well worth the effort. It is peaceful.
I had a couple hours between trains and walked around the Old Town and stumbled into this church and saw the lovely windows. Love the Chagall Windows.

The church itself is nice but not a stand out as far as churches go. However the Chagall Windows are definitely worth seeing. Beautiful. Doesn't take long to go in, admire the windows, then continue your walk through old town.

St. Peter church has the biggest clock in europe and faced to europe. It looks wonderful and kind of landmark of zurich!! Its easy to find it from bahnhofstrasse and everyone welcomes inside church. Inside church is not tremendously beautiful such as European cathedrals but nice

This church has a chapel with Chagall windows, which are absolutely not to be missed! It is located in the heart of town.

The Chagall Windows: wow!! Plan to sit a bit and appreciate this marvelous space, lit by absolutely stunning stained glass windows.

One of the 3 very visible church towers in the old town (the others being Gtossmunster and St Peter's Church). This one has a green roof. The area around it has nice cobbled sloping streets with quaint shops and boutiques. Lindenhof Hollis nearby and worth a detour for its view.
We have visited a concert in Fraumünster. The sound and acoustic was really well to hear the singers, orchestra.
apparently typically "austere" church with little ornament but with the advantage of some rather nice stained glass windows designed by Chagall.

text.wiki:
The FIFA World Football Museum is an association football museum owned and operated by FIFA. The museum is located in Zürich, Switzerland, across town from the FIFA headquarters. It opened on 28 February 2016.


== Exhibits and amenities ==
The 3,500 m2 (38,000 sq ft) museum occupies the lower three floors of the renovated Haus zur Enge, a ten-story mixed-use building located in the Enge quarter across from the Zürich Enge railway station and the FIFA-owned Hotel Ascot. The building also contains a sports bar, a bistro, a café, a library, a museum shop and conference rooms; the upper floors have office spaces and 34 luxury apartments.The museum shows over 1,000 objects. Exhibits include memorabilia from every FIFA World Cup and FIFA Women's World Cup, the most famous one being the original FIFA World Cup Trophy. The exhibition features various interactive and multimedia installations such as the biggest pinball machine ever made and an audiovisual media installation called Visions of Football using 8 meter LED screens.  In 2017, the museum was nominated for the German Design Award.Every year the museum participates in Zürich's Long Night of Museums.


== History ==
Plans for a museum dedicated to the history of world football to be located in Zürich were proposed by FIFA president Sepp Blatter and the FIFA Executive Committee in 2012. In April 2013, FIFA signed a 40-year lease with Swiss Life for the Haus zur Enge, which would be dismantled and rebuilt to house the museum; an earlier proposal would have had a museum on the grounds of the FIFA headquarters. The City of Zürich Building Authority approved planning permission for the museum in November 2013.Construction on the renovated Haus zur Enge began in 2014 and was completed in December 2015.The 30 million Fr. ($30 million USD) museum opened on 28 February 2016, during a ceremony presided by the newly elected president of FIFA, Gianni Infantino.

text.wiki:
The Zürich Opera House (German: Opernhaus Zürich) is an opera house in the Swiss city of Zürich. Located at the Sechseläutenplatz, it has been the home of the Zürich Opera since 1891, and also houses the Bernhard-Theater Zürich. It is also home to the Zürich Ballet.


== History ==
The first permanent theatre in Zürich, the Aktientheater, was built in 1834 and it became the focus of Richard Wagner’s activities during his period of exile from Germany.
The Aktientheater burnt down in 1890. The new Stadttheater Zürich (municipal theatre) was built by the Viennese architects Fellner & Helmer, who changed their previous design for the theatre in Wiesbaden only slightly. 

It was built in only 16 months and was opened in 1891 and became the first opera house in Europe to have electrical lighting.

It was the city's main performance space for drama, opera, and musical events until 1925, when it was renamed Opernhaus Zürich and a separate theatre for plays was built: The Bernhard Theater opened in 1941, in May 1981 the Esplanada building was demolished, and the present adjoint building opened on 27/28 December 1984 after three years of transition in the Kaufhaus building nearby Schanzengraben.
By the 1970s, the opera house was badly in need of major renovations; when some considered it not worth restoring, a new theatre was proposed for the site. However, between 1982 and 1984, rebuilding took place but not without huge local opposition which was expressed in street riots. The rebuilt theatre was inaugurated with Wagner’s Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg and the world première of Rudolf Kelterborn’s Chekhov opera Der Kirschgarten.
As restored, the theatre is an ornate building with a neo-classical façade of white and grey stone adorned with busts of Weber, Wagner, and Mozart. Additionally, busts of Schiller, Shakespeare, and Goethe are to be found. The auditorium is built in the neo-rococo style and seats approximately 1200 people. During the refurbishment, the issue of sightlines was not adequately addressed.  As a result, the theatre has a high number of seats with a limited view, or no view, of the stage. This is unusual in international comparison, where sightlines in historic opera houses have been typically enhanced over time.Corporate archives and historical library collections are held at the music department of the Predigerkirche Zürich.The Opera House also holds concerts by its Philharmonia orchestra, matinees, Lieder evenings and events for children. Opera Ball is organised every year in March, and is usually attended by prominent names.


== Opera Studio ==
The Zürich Opera House is also home of the International Opera Studio (in German: Internationales Opernstudio IOS) which is a educational program for young singers and pianists. The studio was created in 1961 and has renowned artists currently teaching such as Brigitte Fassbaender, Hedwig Fassbender, Andreas Homocki, Rosemary Joshua, Adrian Kelly, Fabio Luisi, Jetske Mijnssen, Ann Murray, Eytan Pessen or Edith Wiens.


== Youth protests of 1980 ==
In response to the combination of high subsidies for the Opera and the lack of cultural programs for the youth in Zürich, large protests were held in May 1980. The protests became known as the Opernhauskrawalle youth protests – Züri brännt, meaning Zurich is burning, as documented in the 1981 Swiss documentary film of the same name.


== Financing ==
Opernhaus Zürich AG is organised pursuant to Swiss law as a company limited by shares and it operates a music theater and Ballet under the authority of Canton of Zurich that has been providing the main funding since 1995.
Both Swiss banks, UBS and Credit Suisse, are partners of Opernhaus Zürich AG.


== References ==


== External links ==
Zürich Opera’s official website
Marco Badilatti (2005). "Opernhaus Zürich, Zürich ZH".  In Andreas Kotte (ed.). Theaterlexikon der Schweiz (TLS) / Dictionnaire du théâtre en Suisse (DTS) / Dizionario Teatrale Svizzero / Lexicon da teater svizzer [Theater Dictionary of Switzerland] (in German). 2. Zürich: Chronos. pp. 1350–1352. ISBN 978-3-0340-0715-3. LCCN 2007423414. OCLC 62309181. [1]

text.wiki:
The Rietberg Museum is a museum in Zürich, Switzerland, displaying Asian, African, American and Oceanian art.  It is the only art museum focusing on non-European art and design in Switzerland, the third-largest museum in Zürich, and the largest to be run by the city itself.  In 2007 it received approximately 157,000 visitors.


== Location and buildings ==
The Rietberg Museum is situated in the 17-acre (69,000 m2) Rieterpark in central Zürich, and consists of several historic buildings: the Wesendonck Villa, the Remise (or "Depot"), the Rieter Park-Villa, and the Schönberg Villa.  In 2007 a new building designed by Alfred Grazioli and Adolf Krischanitz was opened – the addition of this largely subterranean building, known as "Smaragd", more than doubled the museum's exhibition space.The Rieterpark is located near Zürich Enge railway station, and can also be reached by tram line #7 and bus line #33.


== History ==
In the early 1940s the city of Zürich purchased the Rieterpark and the Wesendonck Villa.  In 1949 the Wesendonck Villa was selected, by referendum, to be rebuilt into a museum for the art collection of Baron von der Heydt, which he had donated to the city in 1945.  This was carried out in 1951-52 under the architect Alfred Gradmann.  The Rietberg Museum was opened on 24 May 1952.  Johannes Itten, the Swiss expressionist painter, was director of the museum until 1956.
In 1976 the city acquired the Schönberg Villa, which had been threatened with demolition, and opened it in 1978 as an extension of the museum.  Today the Villa is also home to an extensive non-lending library administrated by the museum.


== Organisation and funding ==
The Rietberg Museum is operated by the presidential department of the city of Zürich.  In 2007, it employed around 100 people.  About half of the funding comes from the city, while the other half is raised through revenue, sponsors, and donations.  Additions to the collection come mostly from donations.


== Publishing activities ==
The museum established an in-house press shortly after its founding in 1952.  Initially it published catalogues of the museum's Asian and African artworks, as well as occasional short monographs.  The museum's publishing activity has increased since 1985, in connection with the large special exhibitions that it has organised since then, and it now publishes four to six new titles per year.
Since 1991, the museum also publishes Artibus Asiae, a biannual scholarly journal on the arts and archaeology of Asia.

== External links ==

text.wiki:
Die Altstadt (German for "the old town") in the Swiss city of Zürich encompasses the area of the entire historical city before 1893, before the incorporation of what are now districts 2 to 12 into the municipality, over the period 1893 to 1934. Die Altstadt approximately corresponds to the area enclosed by the former city ramparts, and is today within the administrative area of the city called Kreis 1 (District 1).
With a population of 5,617 (as of 2015), it houses about 1.4% of the city's total population.
Administratively, District 1 is divided into four parts or quarters by the Zürich statistical office, Rathaus (town hall), Hochschulen (universities), Lindenhof ("lime trees courtyard") and City. Lindenhof and Rathaus correspond to the parts of the medieval city left (west) and right (east) of the Limmat, respectively, while City and Hochschulen include the area of the Early Modern city west and east of the medieval walls, respectively.


== Lindenhof ==

Der Lindenhof ("The lime trees courtyard") quarter corresponds to the mindere Stadt, the smaller but more prestigious half of the medieval town left of the river. This is the oldest core of the city, with settlement traces dating to pre-Roman (La Tène) times, and fortified as the Roman Vicus Turicum, a Roman customs station with a surrounding civilian settlement, in the final decades of the 1st century BC.
The Lindenhof hill itself is the site of the Roman castle at the location of the Celtic Oppidum Zürich-Lindenhof, rebuilt in Carolingian times but derelict by the 13th century, when it was used as a source for building stone for the first stone houses of rich burghers of the recently reichsfrei city. The Schipfe quarter at the Limmat below the Lindenhof is the site of the Roman vicus, with traces of a hypocaustum nearby the Münsterhof excavated. St. Peter church was the parish church of the medieval city, built on the site of an earlier temple to  Jupiter.
The Rennweg street below the Lindenhof hill was the main street of the medieval city, entering by the Rennweg gate through the western city wall which is now marked by the course of Bahnhofstrasse. Augustinergasse is a small street leading from St. Peterhofstatt situated at the St. Peter church, passing the former Augustinians monastery below the Lindenhof hill, towards the Kecinstürlin gate at the southern Fröschengraben moat, Bahnhofstrasse as of today.
Zunfthaus zur Meisen at Münsterhof plaza near Fraumünster church houses the porcelain and faience collection of the Swiss National Museum. Lindenhof also contains the former Augustinian abbey, and formerly the Oetenbach nunnery north of the Lindenhof hill, demolished in 1903 to make way for the Uraniastrasse as part the partially built «Urania-axis» Sihlporte–Uraniastrasse–Zähringerplatz by Gustav Gull, and the Urania Sternwarte.


=== Fraumünster ===

The Fraumünster ("women's minster") abbey ruled the town until the 1336 "guild revolution" of Rudolf Brun and which remained highly influential until Zwingli's Reformation.


== Rathaus ==

The Rathaus quarter is named for the town hall, built in the 1690s.
It is the part of the medieval town on the right side of the Limmat,  separated by the Hirschengraben from the Hochschulen quarter to the east, and delimited by the Bellevue and Central squares to the south and north, respectively. As such, it includes the Limmatquai as well as the Niederdorf (downstream of the Kirchgasse) and the Oberdorf (upstream of the Kirchgasse). The historical name of this eastern half of the medieval town was "greater town" (mehrere Stadt), contrasting with the "lesser town" (mindere Stadt), the western half along the left river bank.


=== Limmatquai ===

The Limmatquai was built along the right side of the Limmat, running from Central to Bellevue. It was built in the 19th century, connecting various earlier quais built into the Limmat. The current right bank is some 28 m west of the medieval river's. The quai was constructed from 1823–1859 from Bellevue to the Rathaus, in 1835–1836 from the Rathaus to the Wasserkirche and 1835–1839 the portion from the Wasserkirche to Bellevue, formerly called Sonnenquai. At the Limmatquai are located some guild houses, as Zunfthaus zur Zimmerleuten, Zunfthaus zur Haue, Zunfthaus zum Rüden and Zunfthaus zur Saffran.
Zürich tram routes 4 and 15 run along the Limmatquai, serving the stops Helmhaus, Rathaus and Rudolf-Brun-Brücke. The quai was one of the main routes through the old town before it was freed from traffic in 2004.
The bridges passed by the Limmatquai, south to north, are:

Quaibrücke, connecting Bellevue and Bürkliplatz,
Münsterbrücke between Grossmünster and Fraumünster,
Rathausbrücke just north of the town hall,
Rudolf-Brun-Brücke, between Mühlegasse and Uraniastrasse,
the Mühlesteg footbridge
Bahnhofbrücke, between Central and Zürich Hauptbahnhof.north of Limmatquai:

Walche-Brücke
the Drahtschmidlisteg, a footbridge to Platzspitz


=== Niederdorf ===
The Niederdorf (lit.: "low village") was the least developed part of the medieval city. It properly includes just the north-eastern corner, between Mühlegasse and Central, but the term was extended to the whole part of the mehrere Stadt north of the town hall, i.e. for the entire length of the Niederdorfstrasse, or even including the parts north of the Kirchgasse.So defined, the Niederdorf includes Rindermarkt and Neumarkt, Froschaugasse and the area of the medieval Jewish quarter, the Predigerkirche (the former Blackfriars' monastery) at Zähringerplatz (historically the city hospital, now housing the city library) and the Zähringerstrasse.


=== Münstergasse ===
The mehrere Stadt between the Niederdorf and the Oberdorf (between Rathaus and Kirchgasse) includes the Münstergasse, Obere Zäune, Untere Zäune and the Barfüsserkloster (the former Franciscan abbey) as well as a number of alleys leaving Münstergasse:  Marktgasse, Spiegelgasse, Krebsgasse, Ankengasse, Römergasse and Kirchgasse.


=== Grossmünster ===


=== Predigerkirche ===

Initially the church of the Predigerkloster (Dominican monastery), it became after the Reformation in Switzerland the parish church of Niederdorf respectively Neumarkt, and owns since 1900 the tallest church tower of Zürich.


=== Oberdorf ===
The Oberdorf (lit.: "upper village") proper is the mehrere Stadt south of the Grossmünster, along the Oberdorfstrasse, between Kirchgasse and Rämistrasse.


== Hochschulen ==

Hochschulen (universities) is wedged between Hirschengraben (the historical course of the eastern moat) and Rämistrasse, corresponding to the area taken up by the eastern fortifications of the 17th century ramparts (destroyed following the 1839 Züriputsch), the hillside now holding the main buildings of both ETH Zurich (built 1861 to 1864 under Gustav Zeuner) and University of Zurich (built 1914 under Karl Moser), at the sites of the Kronen Bollwerk and Schönenberg Bollwerk ramparts, respectively. Hochschulen borders on District 6 (Unterstrass and Oberstrass) to the north, on District 7 (Fluntern and Hottingen) to the east and on District 8 (Mühlebach) and Seefeld) to the south.
Hochschulen in its southern end also includes the Bellevue and Sechseläuten squares as well as the theater and opera house at Stadelhoferplatz and the Stadelhofen train station. Stops of the Zürich tram system in the Hochschulen quarter are: Central, ETH/Universitätsspital, Kantonsschule, Kunsthaus, Neumarkt, Bellevue, Opernhaus and Stadelhofen. Line 9 follows  Rämistrasse which separates Hochschulen from Fluntern, line 3 follows Hirschengraben and Seilergraben (the historical eastern moat), which separates it from the Rathaus quarter. The Polybahn funicular connects Central and the ETH Zurich main building.


=== Central ===
The Central square at the northern border between Rathaus and Hochschulen quarters is a major junction of the Zürich tram system, served by lines 3, 4, 6, 7, 10 and 15 besides buses 31 and 46. Formerly called Leonhardsplatz, it was renamed after the Hotel Central built in 1883.


=== Pfauen ===
Situated at Heimplatz, vernacularly called the Pfauen, are the theatre Schauspielhaus Zürich and the art museum Kunsthaus Zürich.


=== Bellevue ===

The Bellevueplatz, a square at the southern border between the Rathaus quarter and the southern end of the Hochschulen quarter, right next to the lake outflow, is a major junction of the Zürich tram system, served by lines 2, 4, 5, 8, 9, 11 and 15 besides buses 912 and 916. It is situated at the lakeside, just north of Sechseläutenplatz. It is named for the Grandhotel Bellevue built in 1856, and is the nodal point of the quaysides that were built between 1881 and 1887 crossing the Quaibrücke towards Bürkliplatz and General-Guisan-Quai.


=== Stadelhofen ===
South of Bellevue are the squares Sechseläutenplatz and Stadelhofenplatz. Stadelhofen was an estate just south of the southeastern-most bastion, the Stadelhofen Bollwerk, whilst Sechseläutenplatz takes its name from the Sechseläuten, a traditional Zürich festival that is celebrated there.
Stadelhofen station, on Stadelhofenplatz, is an important stop of the Zürich S-Bahn lines to Uster, Rapperswil-Jona and Winterthur as well as the terminal of the Forchbahn (S18) line serving Zumikon and Esslingen. The Zürich Opera House is situated at the southern end of the Sechseläutenplatz.


== City ==
City is the area west of the Bahnhofstrasse, delimited by the Sihl and the Schanzengraben, the moat of the 17th century ramparts. It includes the Paradeplatz, Zürich Hauptbahnhof, the Swiss National Museum and the Platzspitz park (formerly Limmatspitz). It comprises the tram stops Bürkliplatz, Paradeplatz, Rennweg, Bahnhofstrasse / Bahnhofplatz / Bahnhofquai, Löwenplatz, Sihlstrasse and Bahnhof Selnau. City borders on District 2 (Enge) to the southwest, and on Districts 4 and 5 (Aussersihl) to the northwest.


=== Platzspitz ===

Platzspitz (formerly Platzpromenade, Limmatspitz) is a park at the confluence of the two rivers of Zürich; the Limmat and the Sihl.
In medieval times, the area situated north of the city was used as pasture. In the early 15th century it was made into a shooting-range, and in the 16th to 17th centuries, Schützenfeste were held there. A remnant of these can be found in the contemporary Knabenschiessen shooting contest.
During the 1990s, the long-practised official tolerance of drug users there from throughout Central Europe has been the subject of much worldwide media interest.


=== Hauptbahnhof ===


=== Bahnhofstrasse ===


=== Bürkliplatz ===

Bürkliplatz is a square and stop of the Zürich tram system (lines 2, 4, 8, 9, 11 and buses 161, 165), situated at the southern end of the Bahnhofstrasse, and west of the Bellevue square, with which it is connected by the Quaibrücke. The lakeshore quay connecting the square with Lake Zurich is named General-Guisan-Quai, after Henri Guisan. From the Bürkliplatz landing gate, Zürichsee-Schifffahrtsgesellschaft boat services leave for Thalwil, Rapperswil, Schmerikon, Erlenbach and down the Limmat to Zürich Landesmuseum. Bürkliplatz is named for Arnold Bürkli (1833–1894), the engineer responsible for the construction of the city's quays.


=== Schanzengraben ===

On its remains at «zur Katz» ramparts, the Old Botanical Garden is located.


=== Selnau ===
Selnau (from earlier Sellnau, Seldnau) was historically an estate west of the city, which came to lie between the north-western moat (Schanzengraben) and the Sihl. Together with the Gessnerallee, Selnaustrasse and Sihlhölzlistrasse running along the right bank of the Sihl, it is part of the City quarter even though strictly situated outside the city ramparts. Today, Zürich Selnau railway station is a stop on the line of the Uetlibergbahn, running from  Zürich Hauptbahnhof to the Sihltal (S4) and to the Uetliberg (S10). The SWX Swiss Exchange building is located in Selnau. The museum Haus Konstruktiv is located in a former power station near Selnau train station.

text.wiki:
The Chinese Garden (German: Chinagarten Zürich) is a chinese garden in the Swiss city of Zürich. It is a gift from Zürich's Chinese partner town Kunming, dedicated to the Three Friends of Winter.


== Location and history ==
Zürich's Chinese garden is located in the city's Seefeld quarter, next to the Pavillon Le Corbusier between Blatterwiese and Bellerivestrasse and near to the Zürichhorn peninsula on the right shore of Zürichsee. Ending winter season, the garden will be opened on March 18 to October 18, daily from 11:00 (am) to 19:00 (7 pm), even on Sundays and public holidays. Verkehrsbetriebe Zürich tram lines 2 and 4, together with bus line 33, serve nearby stops at Höschgasse or Fröhlichstrasse, whilst bus lines 912 and 916 run from Bellevue to Chinagarten.
The garden is a gift by Zürich's Chinese partner town Kunming, as thanks for Zürich's technical and scientific assistance in the development of the Kunming city drinking water supply and drainage. From May to October 1993, it was built under the direction of the Zürich garden department, in cooperation by garden experts and craftsmen from Kunming and Zürich, paid by Zürich city administration. Its official inauguration was in spring 1994, under participation of the now former mayor of Kunming City and Zürich's Josef Estermann. As from 2010 maintenance and operation are provided by Grün Stadt Zürich, the City of Zürich's Office of Parks and Open Spaces being a service of the Civil Engineering and Waste Management Department.


== Landscaping and buildings ==

The garden covers an exactly rectangular terrain, surrounded by a low wall. Its central element is a pond with a small island.
The surrounding wall separates the outer mundane world from art, an ideal microcosm in the garden inside – offers protection against unwanted visitors, too. The wall has on three sides windows, with barred bamboo and lotus flower tiles. Eaves and final bricks as well as the frieze bear small sculptural figures, representing the Chinese dragon of clouds. Wall corners and wall's top adorns the second of the nine dragon sons, Chiwen dragon.
The main portal (entrance) is emblazoned with a calligraphy on a golden plate, meaning China Garden. Nine nail rows and the red color of the gate originally were reserved for the emperor. In China's Yunnan province, for 300 years they have been an essential architectural element of garden plants. The second door was originally named the second-last gate of the Imperial Court's inner rooms. The carved panels on both sides, are excerpts from Chinese tales. The artificial mountain represents the meaning of landscape – «Mountain und Water» – and is contrasting Yin and Yang. Rock formations are the bones in the body, focusing the garden. They also are sharing space and draw the viewer's gaze.
A bridge is connecting the pavilion's island and the inner garden, reminding the island of immortals. The circular pavilion embodies the middle, and so the fifth cardinal direction in the culture of China. His inscriptions refer to the water as a symbol of friendship between the cities of Kunming and Zürich. The hectagon pavilion suggests lofty heights and snow drift in winter. His carvings are full of allegories: Phoenix as symbol of empress, and flowers as well as a symbol of female beauty. The pavilion's inside is showing symbols of good luck and landscapes. A square pavilion forms the entrance to the galleries and to the water palace. Its entrance shows two golden Phoenix'. A carved archway is devoted to the spring, a magpie and plum blossoms announce the newly waked life. Open galleries are adorned by more than 500 still lifes and landscapes. Its carved arche beams are a particular feature of the gardens of Yunnan. A short  winding path symbolizes abundance and harmony.
The water palace is the heart of the Chinese garden. The painting of its exterior walls, doors and windows is deliberately kept simple, so that visitors are able to concentrate to the inner qualities of the building. Its terrace opens to the water surface, showing all important elements of the garden, its rear garden is called garden of shadows.


== Plants and water world ==
The garden is an expression of one of the main themes of Chinese culture, the «Three Friends of Winter» – three plants that together brave the cold season – pine, bamboo and plum blossom. The inscriptions and paintings point to the uniqueness of the culture of Yunnan and its influences from various ethnic groups. Trees and flowers represent the source of feelings and aspirations. In Zürich's Chinese garden, the local poplars are integrated in the overall design. The pond is lined with willows, as symbol of pure water and holyness. Also important are four ginkgos between the open gallery and the northern wall. Bamboo is representing a forest, with its deep unique sound when wind is blowing. Pine symbolizes the male principle among the trees and a long life. The «Three Friends of Winter's» third part is the plum blossom, beginning to bloom in late winter, and therefore a joyful symbol of spring.
Water is the central element, as a symbol of friendship between Kunming and Zurich. Entering the garden, the pond opens our view to all important elements of the garden.


== References ==


== External links ==
Chinagarten Zürich on City of Zürich administration website
Panoramics and further information on swisspanorams.ch
3D Google Earth model of pavilion.

text.wiki:
St. Peter is one of the four main churches of the old town of Zürich, Switzerland, besides Grossmünster, Fraumünster and Predigerkirche.


== History ==
Located next to the Lindenhof hill, site of the former Roman castle, it was built on the site of a temple to Jupiter. An early church of 10 by 7 metres is archaeologically attested for the 8th or 9th century. This building was replaced by an early Romanesque church around AD 1000, in turn replaced in 1230 by a late romanesque structure, parts of which survive. Rudolf Brun, first independent mayor of the town, was buried here in 1360. The nave was rebuilt in 1460 in Gothic style. Prior to the Reformation, St. Peter was the only parish church of the town, the rest being part of monasteries. The first reformed pastor, Leo Jud (1523-1542), was a friend of Zwingli and contributed to the first translation of the Bible in Zurich. Johann Kaspar Lavater was pastor from 1778-1801. His gravestone can be seen in the church wall. Theologian Adolf Keller served as pastor 1909 -1924.
The current building was consecrated in 1706 as the first church built under Protestant rule. Its congregation forms part of the Evangelical Reformed Church of the Canton of Zürich. Until 1911, the steeple was manned by a fire watch. Restoration work was carried out in 1970 to 1975. The steeple's clock face has a diameter of 8.7 m, the largest church clock face in Europe. The bells date to 1880.
Peculiarly, the church's steeple is owned by the city of Zürich, while the nave is owned by the St. Peter parish of the Evangelical Reformed Church of the Canton of Zürich.


== Church tower and largest church clock of Europe ==
The church tower and the nave of St. Peter do not have the same owner: Until the French Revolution the tower belonged to the former city republic of Zürich, since 1803 to the city of Zürich. Belfry and bells belong to the Reformed Church of the canton of Zürich, as well as the staircase leading to the tower.The church tower was primarily used for fire police duties, and 1340 AD the first fire guard was set in duty. In the pre- and early Romanesque area, St. Peter had no church tower, i.e. the first massive three-storey tower was built in early 13th century AD. The first floor with Romanesque ribbed vault dates back to that period. In 1450 the tower was increased to 64 metres (210 ft) (as of today) and a pitched (helmet) roof was attached. That 24 metres (79 ft) high part of the tower was in 1996 re-covered with 42,000 larch shingles from the Engadine valley, since then being the only wooden roof in Zürich.Towards the end of the 13th century a mechanical church clock was installed. In 1366 it was renewed and got one only dial that was directed towards the Limmat and only displayed the hours. Around 1460, the sense of time has been refined by half on the quarter-hour strike, and in 1538 the striking clock was replaced, and all four facades got dials. Replacements of the clock mechanism followed in 1593/94 and 1675 and 1826. In 1844 a new movement with quarter-hour strike was installed; the electrification of the work was carried out in 1873. In 1972 the balance was replaced by a fully automatic master clock in the clock room of the St. Peter's tower, and  in 1996 the electrified mechanical movement of 1844 was shut down and replaced by a central computer system. The clock tower of St. Peter was for centuries Zürich's 'official local time', and all public city clocks had to conform to it. The church clock of St. Peter has the largest tower clock face in Europe, the outer diameter of each of the four church clocks measures 8.64 metres (28.3 ft), the minute hand 5.73 metres (18.8 ft), the hour hand 5.07 metres (16.6 ft), and the minute crack of the large pointer measures 0.455 metres (1.5 ft).


== Pipe organ ==
The pipe organ was installed in 1974 by Mühleisen Manufacture d´orgues from Strasbourg. It was revised in 1992, 1994 and 1997.

The slider chests instrument has 52 registers on three manuals and 32 pedals.


== St. Peterhofstatt ==
Around the 1st century BC La Tène culture, archaeologists excavated individual and aerial finds of the Celtic-Helvetii oppidum Lindenhof, whose remains were discovered in archaeological campaigns in the years 1989, 1997, 2004 and 2007 on Lindenhof, Münsterhof and Rennweg-Augustinergasse, and also in the 1900s, but the finds mistakenly were identified as Roman objects. Not yet archaeological proven but suggested by the historians, as well for the first construction of the today's Münsterbrücke Limmat crossing, the present Weinplatz square was the former civilian harbour of the Celtic-Roman Turicum.Assumed to be the oldest parish church of Zürich, St. Peterhofstatt is St. Peter's adjoint plaza, analogously meaning the royal court at St. Peter.


== Gallery ==

		
		
		
		
		
		
		
		


== Literature ==
Peter Ziegler: St. Peter in Zürich. Von den Ursprüngen bis zur heutigen Kirchgemeinde. Buchverlag NZZ, Zürich 2006 (in German)


== References ==


== External links ==
 Media related to St. Peter Church in Zürich at Wikimedia Commons

Persons interested in architecture, religion, and history would likely enjoy a visit to St. Peterskirche, another Protestant church in Zurich. It is not far from the Fraumunster. Most impressive is the steeple’s clock face, which has a diameter of 8.7 meters, the largest
This church and it's huge clock are visable from nearly everywhere in Zurich. The outside outshines the inside.
its the architecture that is interesting here. the inside is rather elegant with a chandelier and columns.
We have seen this church from the outside but did not visit it. Impressive is the big clock on the tower.

On our way to the Lidenhofplatz, we visited the 3rd of the main churches of Zurich. St Peter’s church is easily recognizable because of its huge clock. The clock face measures 8.7 meters in diameter. From ground level, it does not appear this huge. After admiring the tower
I'm not sure this church is a "must do", certainly not compared to other intricately detailed cathedrals that dot the Swiss / European landscape.

We happened to arrived when a choir did an impromptu song. Made our day. It's free and well worth a visit. For every minute the large hand of the clock moves 45cm on the diameter. Inside the church has good proportions and some amazing wooden carvings.
Well worth visiting, for the peaceful calm interior, note photographs not permitted inside. A simple plain interior beautiful stained glass windows and impressive pipe organ.

Sankt Peter is claiming to sport the largest dial of a church or spire clock in Europe; of course our British friends cannot let this small triumph be in our hands, they claim that Big Bens clock in London may sport a dial with some centimeters larger dial but never the less
When we arrived we could not get in as services were going on. However we waited and were glad we did. The beautiful openness and wood were wonderful to see. The tolling of the bells was fantastic.

We had the opportunity to hear a beautiful organ concert here. The inside of the church is rather simple with very few decorations, but the outside boasts a beautiful large clock. This is definitely a beautiful church and for organ concerts it's magnificent

The church was not open when we were there. But the clock tower is so big that you can see it from anywhere in the old town. This alone is worth seeing. The old town is beautiful, but as most cities in Switzerland, very expensive to visit. Switzerland has an incredible Christian

The highlight here is stained glass so go when the sun is positioned to optimize the light streaming from river side. i think that would be morning hours. The wooden interior is nice as well. We also enjoyed the plaza outside with a fountain.

Amazingly huge church tower and clock. Very beautiful and definitely a money shot with your camera. Understated elegance.
Another church that stands out while you're doing your walking around Zurich and another church for some great photos and scenery. You can't miss this when in Zurich. Didn't get a chance to go inside
The church can b recognized by the impressive large clock on the tower that is an element of the Altstadt on the left side of the Limmat.. Nice external appearence, but nothing special inside.

On the other side of Grossmunster lies St. Peterskirche, with its huge clock face gilded with gold paint. The square around it is also very nice and takes you back a couple hundred of years. Definitely a must see in Zurich.

St. Peterskirche is a must see in Zurich. It's a quaint, romantic church which harkens back to yesterday. It boasts the largest clock face in Europe, so one can't really say he's late because he didn't know what time it was in Zurich.
It's a big clock. If you're a clockophile, you'll love it! Otherwise, you can easily pass by without giving it a second notice.

My friend told me it is the largest clock face in Europe! Worth seeing just for that. There are great views of this clock tower from anywhere in the old town. I didn't go inside, but loved how it was an unmissable feature wherever you were standing in Zurich old town!

One of the four main churches/cathedrals in Zurich, St Peterskirche stands tall in the skyline. The clock face is of particular interest and is well worth a close-up look if you have time. The church is easy to find within the narrow streets of Zurich on the south side of River
Not really worth going To, very dissappionting rather do other sights. Clock you can see anywhere from outside

This is a beautiful building, which boasts the biggest clock face in not just Switzerland, but all of Europe! You have to give it to Swiss time-keeping! A must-see! This church is in an area with other "must-see" locations such as the Roman ruins of a centuries old bathhouse

This is just your average Protestant church - still used today and helps add to Zürich's skyline but nothing spectacular. There are some really nice and extravagant churches around Europe but this isn't one of them. Thankfully it's not too out of the way. Go see it, tick it off

The clock tower in this church is simply stunning. Impressive, whatever angle you view it from. The face is massive, visible from a long way away. Worth taking the time to actually walk to and visit the church and admire the clock close hand (forgive the pun!). Take your
this is a simple church far away from the sumptous churches you can see in other cities and countries. it worth the visit but don´t expect much.
A regular protestant church. It is well maintained and clearly actively used. Easy access and central location. Worth checking out if in the area in any case.
Amazing historic church located in old town Zurich. Many shops, cafes and other historic sites near by

the Church is along the Limmat river which is a good location.. All the way you see the big church has very impressive architecture.. Its at a walking distance from Hauptbahnof.. easy to reach & long to stay !!
The church is more interesting from outside than inside. It's a protestant church so there is not much to see inside.
Located at the old town is one of the oldest churches in Zurich.You have to climpe few steps to get in.
On one side of St.Peter square is St Peter Church,Zurich's oldest parish church.The tower dates from c 1450 and has the largest church clock face in Europe,at 8,7 m

Part of the European experience is to visit the churches to se how the local culture interprets its religion. This church does show the changes that came with the Reformation that affected the Swiss people. The history of the Church is quite impressive.
Another of the churches not to be missed in Zurich. Very quiet and spacious with an unusual pulpit. The style inside is very simple but charming. I liked the large vases of sunflowers inside.
Very nice church to visit and a short walking distance from river and lake Zurich. There are other churches in area worth to visit.
If you like the smell of fresh clean crisp air (wish every country had air like this) and specialist designer stores including cuckoo clocks then this is the place for you.
So magical and so whimsical!! its located by the river with Old town on one part and the modern on the other. Just magical and a good walking tour is much needed!!!

We walked from our hotel room to this church and ended up on the downhill entrance (courtesy of Google Maps), getting read to walk away when we noticed a small plaque on the wall showing the entrance on the uphill side. Great work :( Zurich tourism authority. We walked around
Compared to some of the other churches in Zurich this is rather underwhelming. The renovations that were undertaken make this church feel like an opulent hotel room rather than a place of worship.
Nice Place to Visit though the weather wasn't so good the day I visited but there's a provision of seats for u to sit down and not get wet..

This church is really a landmark of Zurich, second only to the Grossmunster, due to its very prominent clock tower - visible and recognisable from almost everywhere in the centre, a bit like the Tour Eiffel in Paris. The tower stands out because of the much lower surrounding
The swiss are known for making great quality watches and with this church they did it again. You can see it clearly from a distance.
Like most of Zurich's churches, this one looks far better from the outside than the inside but still worth popping your head round the door if it is open when you are there.

The church has a fantastic clock tower yet inside is quite plain and functional. This is worthy of a vist but will not take up too much of your time.
This church is famous for its huge clock face. The largest tower clock face in Europe. The church is very simple and the pulpit is central - a very important statement at the time of the Reformation.
The oldest parish church in Zurich, the inside is plain and stark, but the attraction is the outside clock, the biggest in Europe. Still worth visiting and spending some quiet minutes inside.

Unlike downtown Zurich eg Bahnhoffstrasse/Paradeplatz, the old town has no cars or trams, so for that reason is peaceful. This church is on top of hill in the centre of the old town. The hill or area around it is called Lindenhof and is a park full of trees. From one side of it

I didn't go inside this church, but it's absolutely picturesque and worth admiring from afar. Parts of it date all the way back to 1200. Amazing. It has what is claimed to be Europe's largest clock face.
Beautiful church to look at. I heard biggest clock in Europe. It was very pretty at the same time. Nice view from grossmunster.

St. Peter Church is an obligatory passage location. Take the opportunity to enter the church if you have access or enjoy taking pictures of this magnificent monument. I unfortunately when I got there was already closed, but recommend.

its oldest church in Zurich and one of oldest in Swiss, so of course it worth to visit! the architecture is ver nice, and have a very BIG CLOCK TOWER that you can see even from far, and also one of the Oldest clock tower in Swiss.! if you are tourist, you must go and then you

Embrace the timeless and massive St. Peter clock. The clock face is the largest in the world and very visible from downtown Zurich.
It is the oldest church in Zurich. And it is said the clock also is the biggest in Swiss. You may see it from far away.
It is a nice place to visit in Zurich town centre, it is one of the few place that you should visit,
Since not much interesting architecture in Zurich, this is a must. Nothing much really but it's better than nothing.
St. Peter Church is a beautiful landmark that is worth a close-up look. We followed streets by watching the clock tower, and we meandered through several interesting side streets to reach the church.
Just go in as part of the stroll through the old town. Otherwise, there's really nothing particular about the church. Maybe they should let people climb the tower.
A Sunday visit was very nice. The service had not ended but we could go in and sit until it did. That was very nice and welcoming for us. Thank you.

I didn't go inside. I am only commenting on the large clock face. St. Peter or St. Peter's Kirche has a clock face of over 26 feet big. It is very interesting up close, but it is more beautiful across the river. It is a quick walk from the trainstation. If you are walking

This church supposedly has the largest clockface in Western Europe. Station yourself under the belfry at 7 pm and be prepared for an amazing concert of bells! We schedule our dinner reservations AFTER this!
This church is beautiful but what made the visit even better was listening to the incredible organ that was being played as I explored the church. It's a great place to sit and enjoy the music!

Beautiful old Church next to River Limmat and impossible to miss, because of that huge clock up there. I guess this ends up in many photos, because whole Riverside/Old Town Area is a must see in Zürich

If you are wandering through the old town and end up at St. Peter's be sure to take the time to visit the other two churches close by - Grossmunster and Fraumunster. All three are within a five minute walk of each other and worth stopping by at.

Is the first church built under Protestant rule. The St. Peter church in Zurich has the largest clock face in Europe. Awe and devoutness regardless of your believes.
I like the peaceful feels ng and this is a unique reform church. You will find it not same as commercialised church's, it's a good place for resting heart
A very nice, charming Church on a small hill inside Zurich city. On a falls day the evening light shines wonderfully through the windows.

Pleasant to walk around the surrounding streets in the old town. The church has an impressive clock on the outside though the inside is fairly bland

It is a nce church but in touring Europe you will invariably see thousands of churches so it makes this one less of a stand out.
...just after London's Big Ben, the watch is the second largest in Europe ... a nice church where often there are concerts as well ...
The main attraction is the bell tower with its huge clock face. The largest in Europe and the gold face is visible from any part of the old city.
